VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: I mean it makes perfect percent sense.

VARNEY: I think that Trump's critics were so overwhelmed with their contempt for the president, with their emotional response to the election. They were blinded, completely blinded at what's really happening in our economy. That's why I say, who would have thought?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: They couldn't imagine it. But look what we've got. And we got to open higher again this morning. We're going to be well above 27,000 on the Dow, and, by the way, Maria, we are now up exactly, exactly $10 trillion in value since Election Day 2016. $10 trillion, how about that?

BARTIROMO: That is incredible.

VARNEY: It sure is.

BARTIROMO: What a number, Stu. Spot on.

VARNEY: Love it.

BARTIROMO: All right. I know you'll have more in 15 minutes. We'll see you top of the hour.

VARNEY: You got it.

BARTIROMO: Thanks. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour every day, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right here on FOX Business after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, hey, if the shoe fits, 100 of the rarest sneakers ever made now up for grabs. How you can snag a pair of the world's most coveted kicks, that's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Violence breaking out in an Ohio Courtroom. Cheryl Casone with headlines now. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: This is something else, Maria. This happened when two sons of Elizabeth Pledger tried to jump her killer, Dale Williams. All right. One of those family member was hit with a taser, both of them were arrested. Williams pleaded guilty to that crime back in 2017. His sentencing is rescheduled after that happened.

Well, Air France plans to swap bordering passes for facial recognition on flights between New York's JFK and George Bush International Airport down in Houston. Air France already using biometric boarding in several major U.S. cities including Atlanta, Los Angeles, Dallas. Company wants to bring facial recognition to all U.S. airports by next year.

And bidding starting off in the tens of thousands as Sotheby's auctions off 100 pairs of very rare sneakers. Items include Nike Moon Shoes, which Sotheby experts Nike's Co-Founder handmade using a waffle iron, if you can believe it. Also for sale, self-lacing sneakers modeled after ones that were worn in Back to the Future 2. These rare kicks expected to fetch between $30,000 to $160,000. A waffle iron to make shoes.

BARTIROMO: Oh my God. $160,000.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: OK.

CASONE: They're going to -- it's going to go for crazy (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: And what are you supposed to do with those sneakers, wear them or just put them, like, on a shelf?

CASONE: I'd put them in a really pretty box.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. Would you buy that?

SCHLAPP: If it had Betsy Ross's flag on it, yes.

BARTIROMO: Good one.

BLOCK: I just made a hundred dollar bet with myself that you're going to bring that up and I won. All right.

BARTIROMO: Oh, well, who's going to pay you?

BLOCK: Myself, yes, here -- yes, what else is new?

SCHLAPP: I'll pay you.

BLOCK: OK. Cool.

BARTIROMO: But seriously, these sneakers. The stuff people bid on at auction. I mean these are old, worn sneakers.

MCDOWELL: They were meant -- they -- the sole was made on a waffle iron, at least they were made here in the USA, right, Cheryl?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLOCK: Could you use that -- could you use that to make waffles after that?

CASONE: Yes, right.

BLOCK: That's -- things I -- things I need to not know.

MCDOWELL: Better made than the current crop of sneaks that they're selling to the people.

BARTIROMO: Well, look, that was a ridiculous story about the Nike and the Betsy Ross flag (INAUDIBLE)

BLOCK: Totally ridiculous.

MCDOWELL: Since one flew behind President Barack Obama during his inauguration. Did you see that photo making its way around the internet? I don't think that was photoshopped.

BARTIROMO: No, you're right. Now, let's take a quick break. When we come back, final thoughts from this all-star panel, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The president just tweeting about tariffs. Here's what he just said. "When you are the big piggybank that other countries have been ripping off for years to a level that is not to be believed, tariffs are a great negotiating tool, a great revenue producer, and more importantly, a powerful way to get companies to come to the USA and to get companies that have left us for other lands to come back home. We stupidly lost 30 percent of our auto business to Mexico. If the tariffs went on and on at a higher level, they would all come back and fast, but very happy with the deal I made," writes the president.

He goes on, "If Mexico produces, which I think they will, biggest part of deal with Mexico has not yet been revealed. China is similar, except they devalue currency and subsidize companies to lessen the effect of 25 percent tariffs. So far, little effect to consumers, companies will relocate to the United States. Dagen, you want to respond to the president's tweets? You've been critical of his tariff policy.

MCDOWELL: When he brags about the revenue coming in, he's bragging about taxes. He's bragging about higher taxes. It might not be directly on American consumers, but it is on American businesses importing goods into the United States. And secondly, worry about the debt -- the amount of money we're borrowing just as much if not more than -- because again who are we borrowing it from? China?

BARTIROMO: But do you -- do you agree that though that given China's behavior, their goal is to overtake the United States in terms of our military, national security? He doesn't have a lot of levers.

MCDOWELL: It -- he has taken on China and he's fighting back for literally decade --

BARTIROMO: First president to do so.

MCDOWELL: -- for people in this country for decades were ignored and lied to by politicians and business leaders. So, kudos on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Your thoughts?

SCHLAPP: Yes. Look, I think that the -- if we don't get serious about China, we're in big trouble. This is a national security question as well as an economic question. I just hope we can make the right decisions going forward because it's a lot at stake.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean when you talk about tariffs elsewhere, that's a different conversation. You can't call the China story the same story elsewhere.

SCHLAPP: No. You got tariffs, you got Huawei, and you've got the critical infrastructure in the country.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Hey, as we look at this market rally, Michael Block --

BLOCK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- we've got a market that is about to take off once again. Record high territory. A little celebration in order. It is time to cut the cake. Last hour. We showed you the technicolor lattes. This is the explosion cake that Cheryl brought. And this is LG.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about this cake, Cheryl.

CASONE: OK. It's an explosion cake and you're going to have to definitely -- the big thing about the cake is when you open it up, it's going to kind of, "Explode." It is filled with all kinds of candy.

BARTIROMO: Awesome.

CASONE: The trick is to do it in front of the -- well, in front of the cameras. You got to go.

BARTIROMO: OK. All right.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: This is not -- yes.

BARTIROMO: Too big of a deal here just in case it's not such a big explosion. I want to do it -- all right. And we're going to do it this way so that it's on camera. Here we go. All right. Explosion cake.

CASONE: This is like Beyonce, Katy Perry, they have all ordered this cake, because they love it so much.

BARTIROMO: OK.

CASONE: -- because the --

MCDOWELL: You're doing a very good job on this, Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: I know. Thank you.

CASONE: Oh, there you go.

BARTIROMO: There you go.

CASONE: I see what's in the cake. So it's filled with, like, different, like, different colors, obviously. And then it's also filled with candy, it's covered in sprinkles. It is a vanilla cake, in case anybody wants to know.

BARTIROMO: OK. I don't see much --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: I don't see much, I suppose. All it's filled up for the explosion cake. I mean it's pretty.

SCHLAPP: Did we plug it in?

BARTIROMO: So there's --

BLOCK: This is like Geraldo's vault.

SCHLAPP: What's going on here?

MCDOWELL: I'm glad you said that before I did.

SCHLAPP: Now, did you pay the electric bill?

BARTIROMO: We can cut another piece. Maybe we get more explosion. Here we go.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: Maker is (INAUDIBLE)

SCHLAPP: Oh, hey.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: There you go. (INAUDIBLE) is the baker. She's famous on Instagram by the way. Like she's got like almost 300,000 followers because of this cake.

BLOCK: It's beautiful.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It is very nice.

CASONE: Good job cutting the cake, Maria.

BARTIROMO: And does it -- does it taste good?

CASONE: Well, you tell me. You're sitting right in front of it.

MCDOWELL: I ate -- I tasted one of those little -- the little cake --

BARTIROMO: Oh, the cake balls?

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: How was it?

CASONE: You know what, I'm going to try -- this was the --

MCDOWELL: Yes, take a bite out of that.

CASONE: All right. This is the cake (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Do it. Take a bite.

CASONE: By the way, again, you can have these in SoHo in Manhattan today through Sunday.

MCDOWELL: By the way, there are certain things we don't eat on T.V. and Oreos would be one because you'd get them in your teeth and your teeth are black.

BARTIROMO: She's a brave woman.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's not ice cream, is it? That's cake.

CASONE: It's cake.

BLOCK: Did it explode?

SCHLAPP: It's cake.

CASONE: Here we go. Oh my God. It's so good.

BARTIROMO: Yes? OK. Cool.

CASONE: It's so good.

MCDOWELL: It's not much.

BARTIROMO: Bring on the sugar. All right. This is great. We will -- we will enjoy this cake while we say to our audience thank you so much for joining us. It's been a great week here. Have a great day. Seize the day. Dagen McDowell's got you covered on Monday and Tuesday. I'll see you next week. Matt Schlapp, Michael Block, thank you for joining us.

BLOCK: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Always a pleasure. Cheryl and Dagen, have a great day, everybody. Let's get to "VARNEY & CO." Stuart, take it away.

urn:contentItem:60V8-NTX1-JB20-G4FV-00000-00Trump Touts Federal Response To West Coast Wildfires And Praises First Responders; Donald Trump Travels To Arizona; California Wildfires Have Burned Over 3.2 Million Acres Of Land; Trump Says California Must Manage Its Forest Better; Reward Offered For Suspect Who Shot Two LA Sheriff's Deputies In The Head; Lancaster Man Killed By Cop Was Previously Busted In Quadruple Stabbing; Trump Talks Up Death Penalty For People Who Kill Police; Violent Protests Sparked In Lancaster, Pennsylvania After Police Shooting; Colin Kaepernick Complains About NFL's Social Justice Initiatives; DHS Announces New Enforcement Action On Products Made In Chinese Internment Camps; DOJ I.G. Neither Confirms Nor Denies NBC Report About Probe Into Roger Stone's Sentencing; China's Nuclear Threat; U.S. Plans New Arms Talks Aimed At Limiting Russian, Chinese And U.S. Nuclear Warheads2020-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTLarry Elder, Ken Cuccinelli, Richard Grenell, Marshall BillingsleaNEWSFinancial091401cb.229Trump Touts Federal Response To West Coast Wildfires And Praises First Responders; Donald Trump Travels To Arizona; California Wildfires Have Burned Over 3.2 Million Acres Of Land; Trump SaysCalifornia Must Manage Its Forest Better; Reward Offered For Suspect Who Shot Two LA Sheriff's Deputies In The Head; Lancaster Man Killed By Cop Was Previously Busted In Quadruple Stabbing; Trump Talks Up Death Penalty For People Who Kill Police; Violent Protests Sparked In Lancaster, Pennsylvania After Police Shooting; Colin Kaepernick Complains About NFL's Social Justice Initiatives; DHS Announces New Enforcement Action On Products Made In Chinese Internment Camps; DOJ I.G. Neither Confirms Nor Denies NBC Report About Probe Into Roger Stone's Sentencing; China's Nuclear Threat; U.S. Plans New Arms Talks Aimed At Limiting Russian, Chinese And U.S. Nuclear WarheadsLou Dobbs

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST, LOU DOBBS TONIGHT: Good evening, everybody. Firefighters at this hour are trying to contain nearly 100 wildfires raging across the West Coast. Millions of acres have already been scorched and at least 35 people have been killed in those fires, but dozens of people are missing.

President Trump is on his way to Phoenix, Arizona for a campaign roundtable with Latino voters. The President leaving California just a few moments ago. There he met with emergency officials for a briefing on the wildfires.

During that meeting, the President thanked all of those who are risking their lives to fight the wild fires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: In August, I approved a major disaster declaration for California. I've approved, I think, Gavin about 40 Stafford Act declarations. So very quickly, because we want to get this thing taken care of including fire management, assisting grants to help multiple states stop the fires.

More than 28,000 firefighters and first responders are combating the fires in California, Oregon and Washington; over 230 soldiers are fighting the August Complex Fire, and that's the largest fire in California. That's the big one. That's the biggest.

And we want to thank all of the brave fighters. We want to thank these incredible people, the first responders, service members who are racing to the extreme peril, really put their lives in extreme danger.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And the President is now on his way to Phoenix for a campaign roundtable with Latino voters there. It will be his seventh state that the President has visited in his many days, and where is Joe Biden? Well, we'll find out later in the broadcast.

And red storm rising: the Pentagon today warned that China has developed the capability to threaten the United States with nuclear missiles. Tonight, we'll examine the threat closely. The growing Chinese nuclear arsenal is becoming a true threat.

We're joined tonight by President Trump's Special Envoy for Arms Control, Ambassador Marshall Billingslea to take up those issues and more.

As the Pentagon warns about China's growing military strength, this country's attention is drawn to the infernos burning out of control in western states. A combination of heat, drought, lightning, arson, and overgrown forests all contributing to those fires, and well, you probably won't hear this in the left-wing national media this evening, but California's radical Dem Governor Gavin Newsom, who is often well, in opposition to President Trump was profuse in his expression of gratitude today to President Trump for all that he has done for the State of California to fight those fires.

Gavin Newsom, thanking the President for his support of first responders and giving the state critical aid in their response to the wildfires.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. GAVIN NEWSOM (D-CA): There's over 16,500 firefighters currently out in the lines, and I'm very pleased and I'm very grateful, Mr. President, that you're recognizing some of the other heroes, those National Guardsmen and women that did an extraordinary job saving the lives of hundreds and hundreds of people stranded with some of these most intense fires.

I want to thank you and acknowledge the work that you've done to the media in terms of your response to our F MAG Request 14. We were just talking -- Mark Ghilarducci is the Head of the Office of Emergency Services -- has made the record that the state's received in the F MAG support, as well as the major disaster declaration, which you reference on August 22, which was profoundly significant not only to help us support our mutual aid system, but also individuals that are in desperate need of support.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Well, it was only last month that the Trump administration and the State of California signed an agreement to thin up to a million acres of forest in California every year using logging and controlled burns. Governor Newsom further thank the President for funding that effort and acknowledged California has decades of negligence in managing their forests.

California is also the center of the latest violent incidents of Black Lives Matter and in Antifa violence. $100,000.00 reward is being offered tonight for information on the gunman who just brazenly shot two Los Angeles County Sheriff's Deputies from ambush. The two Deputies were in their patrol car, Saturday, in Compton, California when the shooter opened fire at point blank range.

Doctors performing surgery on both Deputies, they are expected to survive. The Sheriff there calls it a double miracle.

As the two Deputies were fighting for their lives, however, Antifa and Black Lives Matter thugs tried to block the emergency entrance to the hospital. Their antics disgusting, even the left and they turned even uglier as they chanted outside the hospital that they hope the Deputies would die.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: These pigs out here, they are telling us that we cannot come in here and see these individuals who have been shot down.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oink, oink, oink, oink. [Bleep] the police. [Bleep] the police. [Bleep] you all.

You all are going to die one by one. This thing ain't going to stop. [Bleep]. [Bleep].

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We'll be glad to send this video along to every corporation in the country who is spending money and efforts supporting Black Lives Matter. I hope we could have a discussion, any one of you who would like to take this up on this broadcast, any CEO of any corporation doing so is welcome on immediate notice to join us on the broadcast here to take up what you were watching and what you are witnessing and what the whole country is repulsed by and why is Corporate America supporting a Marxist organization, this vile and this violent?

We'd like to hear why your company is supporting them. Just give us a call. We'll put you on the air.

And another graphic image capturing the Deputies after they were shot. They were able to find sufficient cover to radio for help themselves after they were attacked so viciously.

And last night, at a rally in Henderson, Nevada, President Trump condemned those thugs, condemned the vicious effort to assassinate our law enforcement officers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The radical left in America is waging open war on law enforcement. Hundreds of officers nationwide have been injured in left-wing riots and mobs, you see it.

Biden wants to appease domestic terrorists, and my plan is to arrest domestic terrorists.

[CHEERING AND APPLAUSE]

TRUMP: And we also believe that if you murder a police officer, you should receive the death penalty and that's something that's --

[CHEERING AND APPLAUSE]

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Los Angeles certainly not the only large Democrat-run city where police officers were attacked. Police officers responding to a domestic violence call in New York yesterday met by a gang member who fired a half dozen shots at them. None of the officers were wounded. The gunman was captured and arrested.

And violence running rampant in other large Democrat-run cities. Yes, they are Democrat-run cities. In Lori Lightfoot's Chicago, 54 people were shot this weekend, and 12 of them were killed. And still, she is the mayor.

And police in Lancaster, Pennsylvania forced to use teargas last night to move a violent mob out of the streets. Black Lives Matter activist again, throwing bricks trying to damage vehicles, calling officers the real KKK.

[VIDEO CLIP PLAYS]

DOBBS: The ignorance, the violence, absolutely incredible, and it's being tolerated by those Democrat-run cities. All of that, by the way by the activist, the thugs, the mob in response to a fatal police shooting of a man by the name of Ricardo Munoz.

Police shot and killed the 27-year-old man as they responded to a domestic disturbance call yesterday afternoon. Police officer body camera video shows Munoz actually threatening those officers with a knife in his right hand before he was shot and shot dead.

Police record show Munoz had been arrested just last year for stabbing four people and holding a knife to his own throat when police tried to intervene. Munoz was awaiting trial on four counts of aggravated assault. No one has explained what he was doing on these increasingly evil streets.

Well, it's stunning to see what America is putting up with in what some celebrities are celebrating in this country. It's pure ignorance. And I have to tell you, it is absolutely intolerable.

Turning now to Wall Street where the market started this week off well. The Dow Jones Industrials rallied, up 327 points. The S&P up 42 points. The NASDAQ up 203. And my goodness, that's right, 203 points. Technology is back in vogue, at least in today's session.

And crude oil up slightly to $37.00 a barrel, and a reminder to listen to my reports three times a day on the Salem Radio Network.

Up next anti-Trumper Alexander Vindman, you'll remember him. He carries on his lies and of the left in a new interview, and it comes, well, in a very familiar package.

We take it up with former Director of National Intelligence, Ric Grenell here tonight.

Also more bad numbers for the NFL, how player protests are being viewed by fans. Radio host Larry Elder joins us on that and much more.

And please, preorder my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." It's available now at our new merchandise store at loudobbsshop.com, a place for all American patriots -- Republicans, Democrats, and Independents; and I'll be doing a virtual book signing September 23rd and get your autographed copy of "The Trump Century." Sign up at loudobbsshop.com.

Stay with us. We are coming right back.

DOBBS: Breaking news now. Obama Attorney General, Eric Holder is advising China Joe Biden on how to steal the election. Biden beefing up his legal team to prepare for what are anticipated issues with this election, as it's been put by one wag.

The legal team includes, of course attorneys from Perkins Coie. You'll remember them. They are counsel to the D.N.C., to Hillary Clinton, to the left in this country. And they Biden the legal team is being led by Obama's former personal attorney, Dana Remus, who actually taught a law class last year at Duke's Law School with RINO Senator Mike Lee. Michael Lee, apparently playing, I guess, Lindsey Graham to John McCain, and that relationship.

Also breaking tonight, the latest FOX News poll finds only 48 percent of Americans say that the violence on our cities including New York, Portland, Kenosha, are riots. Forty percent just don't believe they're lying eyes and say the demonstrations are simply protest. Well, there we are.

"The Atlantic" magazine, by the way, publishing an article this weekend arguing -- if you can imagine this -- that Republicans should permit Joe Biden to win in November. Now, this is "The Atlantic" mind you because they reason, if Biden were to lose, there would be more riots. Does this sound like a threat to you? Because it certainly does to me.

Brookings Institute senior fellow, Shadi Hamid wrote, quote, "A loss by Joe Biden under these circumstances is the worst case not because Trump will destroy America, (he can't)," parenthetically said Shaid Hamid, "... but because it is the outcome most likely to undermine faith in democracy, resulting in more of the social unrest and street battles. For this reason, strictly law and order Republicans who have responded in dismay to scenes of rioting and looting have an interest in Biden winning."

Hamid is saying basically, if President Trump is reelected, the left will give us more riots, more violence, and more ignorance, and he thinks that is somehow going to intimidate voters, so does "The Atlantic." What a strange organization.

Well, the ratings for the NFL's opening Sunday Night Football game between the Cowboys and Rams down more than 20 percent compared to last year. During the playing of the National Anthem and a black national anthem over the weekend, seven teams stayed in the locker rooms, 10 teams had many of their players taking knees and obviously, some fans really did not like it.

Despite the extensive protest, former quarterback, Colin Kaepernick complained calling the league's social justice initiatives propaganda. Can you believe this?

This was never about a protest for him. It looks more like a Marxist drive to overthrow the country. Now, all of that pandering and compliance and accommodation by Roger Goodell and the rest of the NFL going for not Colin Kaepernick just being who he is.

Well joining us tonight is Larry Elder, host of "The Larry Elder Show" on the Salem Radio Network, also executive producer of the documentary, "Uncle Tom: An Oral History of the American Black Conservative."

Let's start with Kaepernick. I can't believe this guy. He has been treated like a rock star and now he is -- and Roger Goodell has done everything but kneel himself before the great activist, Marxist, whatever you want to call him, Kaepernick. They bowed down every time he says anything. So does Nike. So do too many, in my opinion, corporations in this country, public corporations who are turning over money, airtime and supporting him and the left in this broad side. Your thoughts?

LARRY ELDER, RADIO SHOW HOST, SALEM RADIO NETWORK: Well, it shows you how well the Trump economy is doing notwithstanding the coronavirus pandemic shutdown, because Colin Kaepernick apparently is working.

Look, I'm keep waiting for just one of these athletes, Lou, just one aside from Herschel Walker to stand up and say, where's the evidence that the police are mowing down black people just because they're black.

We're in a nation of 350 million Americans, 50 million have police interactions with them every year. Out of that 50 million police-civilian interactions, 11 million people are arrested. Out of that, 60,000 officers are assaulted, 50 are killed. Despite all of that, only a thousand people are killed by the police every year and that's been the same average for the last four or five years. Almost all of them have been resisting with a weapon or resisting violently.

When you're looking at unarmed white cops killing unarmed blacks. You're talking about less than four percent of the total, and unarmed does not mean not dangerous. Michael Brown was unarmed, but his DNA was found on the cop's gun.

My point is, it is very, very, very rare for the police to kill anybody, let alone an unarmed black person, let alone an unarmed black person who is not reasonably perceived as a threat.

The fact is out of all the homicides in this country, unfortunately, half of the victims are blacks, and almost all of them are killed by other black people. It is a fact that a young white man, the number one cause of death for a young white man -- preventable is accidents like car accidents. The number one cause of death, whether preventable or not, for a young black man is homicide, eight to 10 times more likely to be a homicide victim than a young white man. That's why the cops are there.

And finally rapper Tupac Shakur once said, "We need the police more than anybody else because of the criminal element that is there." So knock it off. The facts do not support the whole premise behind the narrative and of getting people killed because cops pull back. It's called the Ferguson effect.

And young black men are being indoctrinated with the idea that they're going to be hurt when they're stopped by a police officer, so they are unnecessarily on guard and therefore are not complying with what they ought to be doing, so you are ruining the relationship on both sides of the transaction by this phony narrative. It's getting people killed.

And I keep waiting for Kareem Abdul Jabbar, Charles Barkley, somebody to stand up with some kind of stature and say, wait a second, let's take a look at the facts before we react. I haven't seen that yet.

DOBBS: Yes, it is to me very interesting that Corporate America won't say, you know, we're really concerned about violence in the black community in our inner cities run by Democratic mayors, these CEOs who are moving money to support these, you know, showboating, you know, spectacles of nonsense that we are forced to watch because it's now part of the NFL. Thank you, Roger Goodell. I mean, it's atrocious.

If they really cared -- if they gave one damn about the problem, the issue -- and fixing it, they will be sending that money directly into those inner cities, and by the way, all of the athletes standing up and showboating and, you know, putting up "End Racism" in their end zones.

This is just absurd, because they are supporting Black Lives Matter and Antifa and all the thugs who have been demonstrating since George Floyd was killed in Minneapolis, and guess what? Dozens, dozens and dozens of people have been killed as a result of the wanton violence on our streets in those Democrat-run cities, and much of it initiated by Black Lives Matter. Not to them, they don't. It is a slogan, and that's where it ends.

ELDER: And look, I point out that people like Doc Rivers, who, after Jacob Blake was shot had a tearful press conference and said, "Why do these kinds of things keep happening?" He lives in Malibu. The end result of his anti- cop rhetoric is going to be the cops pull back, but safety in this neighborhood won't be compromised.

LeBron James, after the death of Ahmaud Arbery says we are afraid to leave the house. We are afraid to leave the house. I guess he speak for all black people now. He lives in Brentwood, and when the cops pull back, he'll be in a very safe neighborhood full of private security. He will not have to suffer the consequences of his irresponsible rhetoric.

Will some prominent athlete stand up and say the truth and knock off the nonsense. As Lou pointed out, Chicago 50 people shot last weekend, the last three consecutive weekends, an average of 50 people were shot, an average of seven people killed. That's just in Chicago alone. And St. Louis and Baltimore have three times the homicide rate. Where's Black Lives Matter?

DOBBS: Yes. And where is Barack Obama? Where is Joe Biden? Where is Eric Holder? And why aren't they speaking up? Three of the political leaders of the left, Biden in particular, he could come out and discuss it perhaps honestly and openly and encourage civility and a peaceful resolution of issues in the black community. Instead, he is hiding.

And as the entire radical -- the party of hate, the radical Dems have become that and I think, now worse.

Larry Elder, it is always great to see you. Thanks for being with us. Appreciate it.

Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi says he got away with it again. He survived a two-week hospital stay. He was being treated for the COVID-19 virus or as it is known here, the China virus. Berlusconi has gotten away with it again.

He is also responsible for our LDT tonight, word of the day, the word is "bunga bunga." So we get actually a bonus word in there -- named for the 83-year-old's notorious bunga bunga parties at his lavish villa while he was Prime Minister of Italy, and there it is.

Up next, the Chamber of Horrors wants more foreign workers in the United States for Big Tech. We will take it up with D.H.S. Deputy Secretary Ken Cuccinelli and more, right after these quick messages. Stay with us.

DOBBS: The Chamber of Horrors complaining again about the Trump administration's restrictions on foreign visas. The Chamber of Commerce are quoted as saying, quote: "It's not so much just bringing the talent into the country, it is having the talent come here to help start new operations." Really? Wow. Who knew?

The Department of Homeland Security is blocking the import of Chinese products made in China's concentration camps. It's about time.

The camps make products like hair products, apparel, cotton, computer parts, and lots of other things as well, and so we have decided to do something about it. Let's find out what. Ken Cuccinelli, Acting Deputy Secretary for the Department of Homeland Security joining us tonight.

Ken, great to have you with us. This is a peculiar, peculiar situation. You're trying to stop this stuff made by Uyghurs primarily in concentration camps, and meanwhile, we are buying nearly everything that China can manufacture across the board.

It's the same Communist Chinese Party responsible for all of it. How do you -- how do how do you expect us to make discreet judgments about what is appropriate, what is not when it's the same lying bunch of murderers who decided that they wouldn't tell the world that the China virus would kill them, and an unsuspecting world found out just how many could be infected and killed in the wanton disregard by Xi Jinping.

KEN CUCCINELLI, ACTING DEPUTY DIRECTOR, DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY AND ACTING DIRECTOR, U.S. CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION SERVICES: So, Lou, the authority that we have to exercise requires us to have a reasonable suspicion on a company by company basis or entity by entity. So a factory today, one of the entities we sanctioned is -- they refer to it euphemistically as a re-education or vocational school. In fact, it's a concentration camp. And I mean, they provide labor to two other entities that C.B.P., Customs and Border Protection has also sanctioned.

So we're hitting the Communist Party directly with their vocational school. We've hit some of these companies with direct sanctions and it stops them from importing their products into the United States.

And this year, C.B.P. has seized tons -- tons -- literally in weight, tons of these products and blocked them from entry into the United States. The Customs and Border Protection under Mark Morgan has issued more withhold release orders, the technical name for these seizure orders than in any other year in its history, directed at China more than any other country. And today, we added five more to the list.

DOBBS: Let's turn to the Chamber of Commerce. They're very upset about not being able to do as they would, which is compete directly against American workers. They're very upset with your administration, and this President because you just won't let him. They just won't -- this President just won't permit the Chamber of Commerce to replace our workers, our middle class with cheap foreign labor.

CUCCINELLI: Well, Lou, this President has been a vociferous advocate for American workers, the American worker and right now, we're several months into the President's exclusion of temporary foreign workers from the United States because of the explosion in unemployment we suffered as a result of COVID-19, and that is slated to go until the end of the year.

And even then the President has, you know, broadcast notice that he may extend it beyond that, so that Americans can get back to work faster, and whether some other people like the Chamber of Commerce would like to get their hands on some cheap labor or not, the President's priority is getting American citizens back to work, and that's what's happening at a record pace.

We still have a long way show, but this President has prioritized American workers first in the recovery.

DOBBS: And good for him and extend it, he should. And by the way, we should point out that the Chamber is so upset with President Trump and his policies that they're going to actually be supporting a number of radical Dem candidates on November 3rd. That's beautiful, isn't it?

Ken Cuccinelli, always good to see you. Thanks so much for being with us. Appreciate it.

Up next, Senators Rubio and Warner blocking Republicans from accessing Obamagate records. We'll take it up with former Director of National Intelligence, Ric Grenell.

Preorder my new book, "The Trump Century: How Our President Changed the Course of History Forever." Available now at our new merchandise store, loudobbsshop.com, amazon.com as well, Barnes and Noble.

Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: Breaking news. NBC is now reporting the Justice Department's Inspector General is investigating something. He is investigating the Department's sentencing recommendation for Roger Stone.

When reached by FOX News, the I.G.'s office wouldn't neither confirm nor deny the NBC report.

Well, anti-Trumper, former National Security Council member, Alexander Vindman talking with "The Atlantic" magazine's Jeffrey Goldberg, the chief editor there and regurgitating the Deep State's lies that President Trump is a pawn of Vladimir Putin.

This comes less than two weeks after at least 20 people disputed Goldberg's article, which claimed President Trump disparaged American soldiers.

Well, joining us tonight is Ric Grenell. He is former Acting Director of National Intelligence, former U.S. Ambassador to Germany, and in my opinion, one of the greatest public servants in this country's history.

It is, Ambassador, great to have you with us. I want to start with the Inspector General, taking up a sentencing recommendation of all that we know could be investigated by the Justice Department to decide on Roger Stone's sentencing recommendation, dropping it from nine to seven years, which is almost double the typical sentence of anyone found guilty of lying to Congress. It's an absurd internal matter that to me speaks to the corruption still within the Department of Justice. Your thoughts?

RICHARD GRENELL, FORMER ACTING DIRECTOR OF NATIONAL INTELLIGENCE: Look, Lou, we have a real problem in Washington, D.C. with the Washington, D.C. types who control the arms of government and they are weaponizing the tools of government against people that they don't like, the opposition, their enemies, their political opponents, and this is really, I think, a crisis in Washington.

We need to be able to clean it up. I know that President Trump feels very strongly as the outsider that coming in, there is a whole bunch of insider rules and regulations and views and it's incredibly difficult to take on the entire system because this system is not only the bureaucrats but it's -- you know, politicians, its reporters.

The Inspector Generals I think are supposed to be above it all. They're supposed to be the individuals who can look at the bigger picture and try to figure out when there are problems, and then deep dive into the specifics.

What we have is a whole group of Inspector Generals who really have been playing politics, and you can go through every single agency in Washington. And it's these Inspector Generals and the entire system that is weaponizing the tools of government.

It's a big problem. And I have to say that when you leave Washington, D.C., and you talk to normal people outside of Washington, D.C., they're beginning to dismiss the whole place. They're beginning to dismiss everything in Washington. That's a very dangerous spot that we're in.

There's a whole group of people in Washington who keep pretending like they matter, and they've lost the American people.

DOBBS: Well, they've lost the American people, but certainly the political parties are looking awfully badly -- both parties -- in all of this and the reality seems to be that the Justice Department is now an organization unto itself. It's where truth goes to die. Documents are not produced.

I mean, look what happened. The Senate Intelligence Committee, Senators Rubio and Warner rejecting Senators Johnson and Grassley's request for documents to assist Chairman Johnson's investigation, and not -- I mean, we are watching a division within the parties that is aimed at, in this case, there's only one explanation. They want to assist the radical Dems who have conspired against President Trump to overthrow a sitting President.

I can't reach any other conclusion logically, can you?

GRENELL: Yes, here let me just say a couple of things. One, Senator Johnson has been one, very few who has focused the Senate on trying to figure out the truth. He is looking for transparency. He is looking for more information.

He is not playing a game of hiding the information that doesn't help his narrative or his mean. That is exactly what many in Washington do. They want to classify and push away reports. They want to create new reports that only look at one side of the situation.

We have very few people, Lou, in Washington who just want to say, let's declassify the information. Let's put it out. The American people are smart enough to look through the information and come to their own conclusion.

We don't need to be spoon fed. We don't need to be told one thing on cable television, and then another when you're under oath inside a congressional committee. We want the whole truth and transparency.

Senator Johnson is looking to do that. He is trying to figure out where this all began and uncover it all and declassify it and give this information to the American people. Transparency is not political.

DOBBS: And transparency is was this President's commitment when he was elected. If indeed we find out that the Justice Department, the F.B.I., all of these investigative agencies and committees produce nothing going into this election, would you recommend -- I'll put the different way -- do you believe the President should declassify every damn document and put it in front of the American -- put them in front of the American people?

GRENELL: Look, it was my job as Acting Director of Intelligence to really question the system and question the bureaucrats who wanted to declassify documents. We over classify.

We now have a system in Washington that classifies to protect the public relations aspect of these agencies. What I tried to do is look at every document and to say, is there a source in here that needs to be protected? Or is there a method that points to how we got this information?

The source and the methods are the only reason why you should protect something. And by the way, you can then just redact that source or that line that talks about how we're getting something.

I also went so far on methods as to say, if the method was finished, if we were done using something, then we should declassify it and share it. If it's something old and useless because we want to show as much transparency as possible, only redact information that is current and relevant.

DOBBS: I'm getting the feeling that you might be willing to entertain declassification. I prefer that interpretation. Ric Grenell who has done so many things to create transparency around what we have come to call Obamagate, I appreciate you being with us. We hope you'll come back soon, Ric Grenell.

Well, up next, the Pentagon says China has the capability to strike America with a nuclear missile. President Trump's Special Envoy for Arms Control joins us with much more on that right after these quick messages. Please stay with us.

DOBBS: Joining us tonight is Presidential Envoy for Arms Control, Ambassador Marshall Billingslea. Ambassador, it is great to have you with us and these are perilous times, and your efforts and those of others in the administration to come to some sort of an agreement on limitation of particularly nuclear weapons and delivery systems among the United States, China and Russia, are critically important.

I want to begin by asking you, how confident you are right now of what can be achieved.

MARSHALL BILLINGSLEA, U.S. PRESIDENTIAL ENVOY FOR ARMS CONTROL: Well, it's great to be with you, Lou, and thanks for giving me a chance to talk with you about the vision that President Trump has laid out for the future of nuclear arms control.

You know, one of the key points that I took from your conversation just now with Ric Grenell is the importance of transparency. And we need to be clear that the same kind of secretive behavior that the Chinese Communist Party adopted when it came to the coronavirus is the kind of stonewalling and great wall of secrecy they are applying to their nuclear buildup.

That's why the President has called them out. He has made clear that they are surging, and that the next Nuclear Arms Control Treaty must include and must limit China.

DOBBS: Well, and Ambassador, I want the audience to know that you have declassified video for us to show what was happening in the arms parade in Beijing, and if we could, let's go to first an image from 2009.

This shows -- well, I'm going to ask you what do you take from this and the size of the parade?

BILLINGSLEA: Well, so Lou, the image that you're showing your viewers there is actually from a classified briefing that I gave to the North Atlantic Council, to NATO a few weeks ago, and we felt it was important, again on this theme of transparency that the American people and frankly, the international community know what's going on.

So on top there, you can see in the parade, the Chinese have one big parade every 10 years or so, where they show off their nuclear weapons. In 2009, you can see that the length of that parade stretched about a half a kilometer. Ten years later, that parade stretched 10 times as long.

So that's what they've done just in the space of 10 years. Can you imagine what it's going to be like 10 years from now, when they continue building all of these different ranges and types of these nuclear capable missiles?

It's very, very concerning and the American people need to know that the President is looking out for them and he is going to protect us through a variety of mechanisms, both improving our nuclear deterrent, bringing online new capabilities that no other nation has, but also in driving arms control to try to limit and avoid an unnecessary and costly three-way nuclear arms race.

DOBBS: Well, I'd like Ambassador, for you to come back and spend some more time with us. We are actually constrained by time tonight. But I want to get a sense from you, again as to your hopes, your optimism about doing something with either Russia bilaterally, or even if that's in the cards are with China bilaterally?

BILLINGSLEA: So that's a great question. The bottom line is the ball is now in Russia's court. The President has had the necessary conversations with President Putin. And we view that they have they have sketched out the way ahead, and that we've made a good a good offer to the Russian Federation, and we hope they'll take us up on it.

What we want to do here is three things. We want to make sure that the next agreement we negotiate and we will start with the Russians first, and we'll include the Chinese in due course, but it's got to cover all nuclear weapons.

We can't have the Russians building all of these tactical nuclear weapons outside of any treaty focused on NATO. And of course, China is not involved in any of these arms control agreements. So that's thing number two.

The architecture we lay out has got to include China. And then thing number three is we've got to fix the really dangerous deficiencies contained in the Obama-Biden New START Treaty, real big deficiencies in terms of verification and transparency measures.

So that's the proposal we've laid out and we're hopeful that Moscow will take us up on it.

DOBBS: Well, Ambassador, we appreciate you being with us in a very instructive discussion. We appreciate it. Come back soon, Ambassador Marshall Billingslea.

Stay with us. We'll be right back.

urn:contentItem:5TD3-MFX1-DXH2-6319-00000-00Trump, Trudeau Praise USMCA Trade Deal They Say Will 'Grow Middle Class'; Brett Kavanaugh Instigated Bar Fight after UB40 Concert, Police Report Reveals; Tesla Do Deliveries Totaled To 83,500 Vehicles; The Execution Factor; Amazon Raises Minimum Wages; Stranded Humpback Whale Rescued In Argentina2018-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMichael Balboni, Lindsey Bell, Ian Bremmer, Jason Rowley, Kim PerellNEWSFinancial100203cb.231Trump, Trudeau Praise USMCA Trade Deal They Say Will 'Grow Middle Class'; Brett Kavanaugh Instigated Bar Fight after UB40 Concert, Police Report Reveals; Tesla Do Deliveries Totaled To 83,500 Vehicles; The Execution Factor; Amazon Raises Minimum Wages; Stranded Humpback Whale Rescued In ArgentinaMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Stuart Varney, Blake Burman

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, October 2nd, your top stories right now, just before 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast, the Art of the Deal, President Trump touting his revised trade agreement with Canada and Mexico.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's my great honor to announce that we have successfully completed negotiations on a brand-new deal to terminate and replace NAFTA and the NAFTA trade agreements with an incredible new U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement called USMCA.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We're taking a look at the implications for business and the economy this morning. Markets are under some selling pressure today. We are off of the lows of the morning. But, nonetheless, down 69 points on the Dow Industrials right now quarter of a percent lower on the Dow, quarter of a percent lower on the S&P, a third of a percent lower on the NASDAQ with the NASDAQ declining 26 points right now. This after a mixed day yesterday.

Pretty good actually, Dow Industrials were up almost 200 points at the close yesterday three quarters of one percent. S&P was up 10 points, a third of a percent. But the NASDAQ was down about nine points yesterday. In Europe this morning, declines across the board. Take a look. The FT 100 down 23 points. BELL: But what about patience? Like, I can understand execution. You got to get out there and make things happen, but you don't make a business to $100 million in revenue overnight, right? So, there's got to be some patience along with the hard work and the dedication, right?

PERELL: Yes. BARTIROMO: Now, you got to tell us more about this. You said you were broke at 23 and now you're a self-made millionaire at 30. How did you do it?

PERELL: A lot of hard work and a lot of execution. So, what I learned over --

BARTIROMO: What did you execute?

PERELL: So, I created a digital marketing company, and right -- you know, I was -- I graduated from college right after Yahoo! had gone public. And I think a lot of people don't know what's next, what's that blueprint for success, and that's where I wrote the book to help, you know, really define what the blueprint is for other entrepreneurs or other individuals that want to start a company, or have a great idea and how to actually get started, because it's really hard go from dreaming and sitting there and having great ideas to actually doing.

MCDOWELL: So, how did you raise the money?

PERELL: So, I -- well, the first company I raised from BC is my own company. BARTIROMO: So, you started with $10,000 and a fund to invest.

PERELL: I -- well, actually, $10,000 in a company to invest from my nanny, grew that to $100 million, sold that company.

BARTIROMO: Wow. 100 million.

PERELL: And then --

BELL: And proceeds from the book are all going to your -- these ventures?

So, how do you -- if for people growing up, coming up just starting out, if their parents didn't instill that spirit in them, where do they go to find it? If not -- if not from inside themselves, if not internally.

PERELL: Yes, I feel very fortunate to have two parents that were entrepreneurs, but similar to your story, they were always looking to make ends meet. And so, having this blueprint and having the action items of how to create and start that company when you don't have that, every great leader that I know is a great reader. And so, giving them the opportunity to read great books, and that's what I did growing up as well is, you know, I learned through others' mistakes and others' failures and how to -- how to not repeat them. So, looking to really pass it on.

BARTIROMO: Great stuff. Congratulations, Kim. Thank you so much for sharing your story.

PERELL: Thank you so much. Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Great to see you, Kim Perell. Breaking news right now from Tesla, the company is reporting that new production and delivery numbers, it delivered a total 83,500 vehicles in the third quarter. This is amid the company's production woes as we know. The automaker produced over 50,000 Model 3 cars, which of course, was the goal. Tesla shares this morning are flat up just a fraction.

Coming up, a warning for Facebook users, hackers could be selling your log- in info on the dark web. Details coming up. Then, a whale of tale. Check this out, a crane, a tugboat, and dozens of volunteers coming together to rescue a stranded whale in Argentina. The incredible video, coming up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news from Tesla, the company reporting new production and delivery numbers this morning. It delivered a total of 83,500 vehicles in the third quarter, amid the company's production woes. The automaker produced over 50,000 Model 3 cars. Michael, your thoughts on this.

BALBONI: So, I happened to be a trustee in New York Power Authority, which is the largest utility in the United States, and on publicly-owned utility. And we have made tremendous investments in the electronic vehicle sector, but what we're finding ironically is that -- are the brakes on this program is the infrastructure to support an electric vehicle, that if you go talk to car manufactures and folks who actually fix cars, they don't have enough people who are trained, mechanically trained in electronic vehicle technology. So, as much as they're going to produce, there isn't necessarily the infrastructure to fix and keep these cars on the road.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's been -- that's been an issue.

MCDOWELL: Well, in terms of the Tesla numbers, this is right in line -- this is exactly what investors would want to hear given the recent settlement with Elon Musk's separate issue, but Tesla produced 53,239 Model 3 sedans in the third quarter. The company said in August it would produce between 50 and 55,000 Model 3s in the quarter. So, this is right where it needs to be.

BELL: Right. And it was -- it was pretty expected by Wall Street that this number was going to come out this week and it would be in line. Elon kind of alluded to it and the market was anticipating it, which is why you're not really seeing the stock react pretty significantly.

BARTIROMO: Pretty much priced in. Meanwhile, then there's Amazon, Amazon's Senior Vice President for Worldwide Operations, Dave Clark, speaking with me earlier this morning, about the company plans to boost the minimum wage to $15.00 an hour. That was a First on Fox Interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLARK: We just announced a change to our Amazon minimum wage across the U.S. to $15.00 for all employees, full-time, part-time, seasonal, holiday employees, everyone is going to be starting November 1st, making 15 -- at least $15.00 an hour just in time for the holiday season.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us to weigh in, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. It seems like a pretty smart move, to me, for a variety of reasons. Number one, there's pressure on Amazon for unionization, I think they're responding to that to some degree. Number two, it's a very tight labor market, you don't want to be short of workers for the holiday season, you got to entice them with $15.00 an hour. Number three, there's a great deal of criticism of Jeff Bezos for his wealth. It's now, what, $165 billion, he can't afford $15.00 an hour for the people who work for him? That's a strong argument. Number four, Bernie Sanders is going after Amazon for not paying a living wage, this answers that charge. And number five, isn't that good public relations right before the holiday season, right before we fire up our Amazon accounts and order everything under the sun? It's a very smart move, it's a very big deal from a very interesting company.

BARTIROMO: Yes, the pressure was there, but I know that they responded to the pressure, but also, we are seeing wages move up, and it's nice to see them do it on their own.

VARNEY: Yes. It's a big deal. I mean, hundreds of thousands of people get this raise.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. 250,000 people in the U.S.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Stuart, great to see you. I'll see you in about 10 minutes. I know you'll have a lot more on it. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, join Stuart at 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, T is for team and tugboat, you won't believe the crew it took to save the stranded whale. The incredible story, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Exposed Facebook users may have more to worry about. Cheryl Casone with the details and headlines. Cheryl?

CASONE: Yes, Maria. So, hackers are selling Facebook log-ins for just $2.60 on the dark Web. We're not worth what we thought we were, I guess. This, according to some new research published by Money Guru. The report came just hours after Facebook revealed a massive data breach that compromised 50 million accounts. The research found that someone's entire online identity could be purchased for about $972. That would include access to online shopping accounts, entertainment services, and social media profile.

Meanwhile, a long time Facebook executive, Adam Mosseri, is going to become head of Instagram after its two founders abruptly resigned last week. Mosseri started at Facebook as designer back in 2008 before overseeing the newsfeed. He moved to Instagram in May to run the product division there. Shares of Instagram's parent company, of course, that is Facebook is trading lower by almost one percent in the premarket.

Well, remember when it was a big deal for stores to open on Thanksgiving Day to kick off Black Friday? Well, it seems the trend is now reversing, BestBlackFriday.com says this year's 60 retailers are going to be closed on Thanksgiving. Costco, Ikea, Sam's Club, Home Depot, and Lowe's are among the biggest names on the list. The site expects that list to grow actually. Last year, 57 percent of Americans surveyed, were against stores opening on Thanksgiving Day.

Well, First Lady Melania Trump is in Ghana this morning as part of her tour of Africa. First stop in her nearly week-long trip, she's also going to visit Malawi, Kenya, and Egypt. The White House says her focus is going to be on maternal and newborn care in hospitals, and children's education.

And then, finally, check this out, a stranded humpbacked whale sent back to the ocean safely after an intense rescue operation was underway in Argentina. Dozens of people worked for nearly 30 hours to rescue this whale. Now, their first efforts was using that crane to move the whale back into the sea failed, but later, they pulled the animal back from the Atlantic Ocean, Maria, they used a tugboat. And you know, we've seen these reports, some (INAUDIBLE) aren't always successful, but this time, it was, and I think it was well worth it for the people on the ground.

BARTIROMO: And he was put back in the wild?

CASONE: Yes, he made it safely out. Again, this always isn't the case with these stories, but this time, it worked out for the best.

MCDOWELL: Can I just point out one story in The Wall Street Journal? It is about making it safely out, animals that escaped butcher shops and abattoirs in New York City, wind up at farm sanctuary up in Watkins Glen, New York, and I know they have their annual fundraiser coming up.

BARTIROMO: Such a nice story.

MCDOWELL: So, this -- like a bull gets -- frankly, the bull gets loose in the streets of Brooklyn, and they lasso him and tranquilized him, he escaped an abattoir in the borough, and they -- he get sent to lead the luxury life up at this farm sanctuary.

BARTIROMO: I love that.

MCDOWELL: So, awesome for farm sanctuary.

BARTIROMO: Oh, what happens to the horse?

MCDOWELL: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: They put him -- they put him back to work, I think, at the racetrack.

BALBONI: Back to the racetrack.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Final thoughts from our all-star panel. And we're following three tracks today, we've got the beginning of the fourth-quarter earnings, of course, expected to be strong. We got the Kavanaugh situation, the showdown to the Supreme Court continuing, we understand there is going to be a vote on Friday. And, of course, then we also have NAFTA, a new NAFTA, USMCA. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Yes, the NAFTA news is great for country, Canada, Mexico, the economy and future of trade deals that will be put together. I've been a naysayer on the tariffs and naysayer on the steel and aluminum tariffs. Those don't go away, but this is a win, pure and simple.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we'll see what it does for the economy. Lindsey --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Odds are going well.

BELL: Right. Things are going really well. And on trade, I would just say that Pepsi came out, they did lower guidance, it was because of the dollar not because of trade and input costs going up because they are, but they're also able to take pricing, so that's important to note.

BARTIROMO: Stock is down 1-3/4 percent.

BALBONI: So, the nation is transfix by the Kavanaugh hearing.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BALBONI: And it ought to be reminded -- the entire process should be reminded that it's not just about the judge, just about the Supreme Court, it's about this quest for power, it's about what it means to our constitutional review capabilities, and the politicization of this court. And there's going to be so many different impacts as a result of this, regardless of how it actually winds up. Now, that's the thing that I think people should really recognize. This is a raw, take no prisoners fight for power.

BARTIROMO: I thought it was really interesting, Dagen, that 86 percent of GOP women back Brett Kavanaugh. 86 percent?

MCDOWELL: Because they see the tactics that the left is using, they're not doing it for -- the Democrats are not doing this for women, they're doing it for their own political power, and to push their own narrative, and to - - ahead of midterm elections, that's very clear why would -- why would Dianne Feinstein and her staff sit on a letter that an accuser against Brett Kavanaugh sent to them and they had since late July, and then they sat on it until it was revealed in mid-September that Dianne Feinstein and her staff had this information.

BARTIROMO: I'll go one step further, why did Dianne Feinstein help Ford get a lawyer? Is that customary? The ranking member of the committee helps the accuser get a lawyer?

MCDOWELL: And then -- and then sat in front of Brett Kavanaugh, I think, it was August 20th in their -- in their sit-down and never brought this up?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But to the point, again, the narrative also that the President is trying to stonewall, the FBI looking to these allegations, that is simply not true. There are no restrictions on who the FBI can question and even President Trump said yesterday himself that he's just waiting to find out like everybody else, what the FBI turns up, period.

BELL: It is definitively going to motivate voters, I think, this midterm election, for sure. It's a hot button for a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: Just about 35 days away. Great show, everybody, thank you so much. Great to see you Michael Balboni, Lindsey Bell, always a pleasure, Dagen McDowell.

MCDOWELL: Great show.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, over to you.

VARNEY: Good morning, Maria, and good morning, everyone. Please cut me some slack.

urn:contentItem:5SW9-WRF1-DY0W-40V3-00000-00Trump Tweets Explosive Threat To Iran President Rouhani; Sergio Marchionne, Auto Legend, Steps Down As Ceo Of Fiat Chrysler2018-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisTrump Tweets Explosive Threat To Iran President Rouhani; Sergio Marchionne, Auto Legend, Steps Down As Ceo Of FiatChryslerLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Earnings in focus, it will be the busiest week for the second quarter reporting season. One-third of the Dow Industrials and S&P 500 set to post results this week. We look at what he numbers and guidance about the state -- the United States economy. We get the reading -- the first reading on second quarter on gross domestic product -- economic growth on Friday.

Look at these futures right here right now. Three-point gain on the Dow futures. Markets searching for direction after the Dow and S&P managed to eke out small gains last week. Although that was your Friday close, it was some small across the board on Friday.

And then moving on, let's check on Europe. We have declines across the board. But contained the biggest loser the CAC Quarante in France down half about half of one percent right now. In Asia overnight, it was mixed markets, the Shanghai Composite and Hang Seng heading higher, the Nikkei and KOSPI in South Korea suffering losses.

Tragedy in Toronto, the death toll rising in last night's deadly shooting rampage. A gunman killing at least two and injuring a dozen others.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard at least 20 shots in intervals, you know, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent. I saw at least four people shot here by the fountain.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is a street where people walk every day to go to the groceries to have dinner, to have an ice cream, sit in the square, enjoy their summer. And it is absolutely devastating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest as authorities work to find a motive. War of words. President Trump threatening Iran with severe consequences if that nation does not take a cautious tone with the United States. And unexpected change at the top of FiatChrysler. The automaker replacing CEO Sergio Marchionne after he suffered complications from recent surgery. What the change means for the future of the company.

Making a private call with a superhero twist. One company creating a private cubicle with a Superman theme. For the first time in decades, oh, EPA chief Scott Pruitt now gone, could have gotten that phone booths in his office instead of the one that he's had taxpayer for. All of that and so much more coming up this morning. CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell.

Look who it is, former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer.

SEAN SPICER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: And Lee Carter, the President of Maslansky and Partners. Sean Spicer has a new book. There you go. We'll talk about it.

SPICER: And you've got a copy of it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. It's not signed. I don't know what's wrong (INAUDIBLE)

SPICER: It will be. It will be signed.

MCDOWELL: It called a briefing. We're going to talk about to Sean about it. Coming up, politics to press and the President. And maybe the President will tweet some this hour and we can get your instantaneous response.

SPICER: Probability is high.

MCDOWELL: All right. He's already been tweeting this morning. So, Mr. President, let's ramp that up to our top story this hour on trade with China. President Trump will host a White House event showcasing American products from all 50 states today following his threats to impose tariffs on all exports out of China and to the U.S. We're talking more than $500 billion worth of annual imports.

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin amplifying the threats saying he "would -- he wouldn't minimize" the chance of this actually happening. And adding that. If Europe believes in free trade, the U.S. is ready for a deal. Joining me now is Ohio Congressman, Jim Renacci. A member of the House Ways and Means Committee, House Budget Committee. Congressman, first did I pronounce your name correctly?

REP. JIM RENACCI (R), OHIO: You did. Renacci, that's right.

MCDOWELL: All right. So what is your take on President Trump's trade threats and have you heard concerns from your constituents?

RENACCI: Well, it's a mixed bag. As I talk talked to my constituents they always say to me, look, we're a little concerned but we want you supporting the President. And it's interesting I've had everybody from soybeans, you know, the agriculture industry into my office to manufactures. Just last week and I always say to him, what do you want me to tell President because I have opportunity to sit with him and what would you rather mew saying?

They go, well, we're concerned but we want to you support him. We want you -- we realize, you know, we have to go through this process. It's amazing because you can't get a straight answer even soybean manufacturer, the growers, I said to them, now seriously, tell me because they come in and they say they're concerned. I said, so what -- so what would your -- if you had a chance to sit down with him what would you say?

MCDOWELL: But their business is being hurt though because they -- because the concern but once people start feeling a real world impact on their livelihoods, it might be different, right?

RENACCI: Well, they are feeling it, they told me they're feeling it but they also understand the need to be able to go through this. They understand the President's negotiating. That's what I tell them. We're in a negotiations phase, let's get through these negotiations. I've had an opportunity to sit with the President car where he says, look, I'm worried about children and grandchildren.

And at some point in time, you know, we need to make sure that we're working through this and give me some time and that's what I tell them.

SPICER: How much time do you think that will give him?

RENACCI: You know, it's going to be interesting. I say that I asked that question too last week and they said -- I said, how much time do you want to give them? And they said, well, let's look at, you know, four, five, six months and we where we're at. So that's ---

SPICER: Because it feels like if you don't do anything, they suffer the consequences of Chinese economic policies. But if you do something that's some short-term pain and I think that's where -- trying to figure out where that balance is.

RENACCI: Well, I was telling them short-term pain, a long-term gain. I mean, that's like --

(CROSSTALK)

SPICER: Right.

RENACCI: And that's like anything else. We have to go be willing to do that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: When you were -- we were just talking to Gordon earlier and he was saying, this isn't going to be short- term pain, this could be 10, 20 years, it's a long game the way that the Chinese play.

RENACCI: Well, and the truth of it is, we have a long game already because the Chinese have been doing this to us for so many years. So now it's time to go through this process. And look, the most powerful message I heard from the President one time was when he said to me, I don't want our children and grandchildren on their knees begging in the future. We have to be willing to work through this.

BELL: Well, I think you saw that in the poll -- the Wall Street Journal poll that came out that people aren't necessarily happy with how he's dealing with trade but his overall rating is going up because I think that the stock market and also, you know, manufacturers, soybean growers and the like, the whole country thinks that this is a negotiating tactic and it's going to end well, but the problem is when does it end?

CARTER: Yes. I think it's also really, really important point though to say can you can be both be concerned and want to support the President at the same time. And I think that a lot of people have missed that because, you think that if you support a President you support him blindly. And I don't think that's the truth. I think most people -- for a lot of people somewhere in the middle depending on the issue.

SPICER: Well, I think that people have been told for a long time that policies going to change and they finally see the President fighting for them willing and they're willing to give them a little bit of latitude to see where this thing ends up.

MCDOWELL: Listen, I have been from breathe one, very concerned about these tariffs that have been slapped on starting with washing machines but then particularly steel and aluminum tariffs and the retaliation that we've gotten from some of our trading but most important trading partners and allies. But the messaging, I want to hit on this, because the messaging from day one when Peter Navarro was on this program quizzing me.

When I wasn't on set about how much is a cost of six pack of beer going to go up. And the Wall Street Journal wrote an editorial last week saying Peter Navarro says the harm is a rounding error and their take was -- well, he is out of touch because there are a number of -- there is a pipeline builder down in Texas that wanted a steel -- a waiver from the steel -- wanted a steel tariff exemption in other company -- another pipeline producer as well.

They didn't get them. And it's going to cost -- it's going to hurt because they're going to delay investment in --

(CROSSTALK)

SPICER: -- construction industry as well in term of the cost of whether it's a beam or a screw. Things are starting to go up and that's costing people money. The question I think that we're just asking the Congressman is how long and how long will tolerate. They want the fight, they've seen Chinese economic policies, adversely affect our economy, our workers too long and they're willing to give the President I think some latitude for a while.

But the question is going to be how long.

RENACCI: Well, I say the same thing but I always tell them let's judge this President. You get a chance to a judge the President in a couple more years in election. So let's judge him then, let's not judge him today. Let's let them go through negotiations.

MCDOWELL: But you guys, well, people go to the polls to reelect you or not come November and on that note let's talk about tax cuts 2.0 which the House is working on, revitalizing the economy, the second round, a big part of the GOP's plan to try and retain control of the House. Here is what House Majority Whip Steve Scalise told Maria yesterday morning on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

VARNEY: Wait a minute, wait a minute. The first thing you think of when you wake up in the morning, is, oh, the Europeans are coming to a trade deal. I don't believe it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, being positive and making sure that you don't look at everything through a negative lens because again, then you miss all the good stuff.

VARNEY: That's the whole point about the Trump presidency, isn't it? Think positive. He's winning, the economy is expanding, we've got prosperity coming at us. You know, think positive, that's why the market is up so much.

MCDOWELL: And even with some mean tweets, that's why his approval ratings are up, too. Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: True. Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, he starts in 10 minutes every day, 9:00 a.m. to noon. Coming up, a phone booth worthy of Superman. Details on the new office cubicle that will cost you over $8,000, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The death toll rising in last night's mass shooting in Toronto. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Dagen, we just got an update from police. A second victim has died from the rampage, a gunman shot 14 people including a young girl in Toronto. The 29-year-old suspect's body was later found at the scene, but it's not clear at this point whether the man actually killed himself or he was shot by police. All of this happened in the Toronto neighborhood known as Greektown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would say I heard at least 20 shots in intervals. You know, clippings spent, reloading, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent, that's what I heard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, investigators are trying to find a motive. Police say they would not rule out, at this point, terrorism.

Well, tragedy in Maryland overnight after a firefighter died while battling a massive seven alarm blaze. The unidentified firefighter, a 13-year veteran fell through the floor. Three people who were inside the house were able to get out, though, in time. The cause of the fire under investigation, but lightning could be the cause.

Well, some stunning news over the weekend at a change at the top for FiatChrysler. Long-time CEO Sergio Marchionne has been replaced. Marchionne underwent shoulder surgery three weeks ago but in those three weeks, his condition has somehow worsened. We're looking for more details. Now, Mike Manley, who runs the Jeep, SUV, and Ram truck division is the new CEO. While the stock is something to watch today, shares are actually lower in the premarket, it's down more than three percent right now. Again, stunning news over the weekend for this company.

Well, a Superman solution for workers who want more privacy, for the first time in 80 years, the Superman cubicle booth is available for purchase. It fits two people inside -- if that makes sense -- it comes with modern necessities like USB outlets and an Ethernet connection, LED lights. You're going to have to make more money than Clark Kent, though, it's actually running about $8500 per booth. And by the way, in the description it doesn't mention to actually having a phone. I don't think people use those anymore, all right.

And then, finally, there is this, we've been watching this clip over and over again this morning on the show. It appears to show a grown man stealing a foul ball from a child. Well, the Chicago Cubs saw the situation play out in real-time. They ended up giving the young boy an autographed baseball instead. But it turns out the man that everybody is criticizing had helped that boy get a foul ball earlier in the game. You can see him holding a game-used baseball next to his new autographed one, obviously. Yes. So, maybe the guy in the clip isn't as mean as we all think, and we're all beating up on him this morning. So, I wanted to, you know, give you some new details on this developing story in baseball. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Glad I didn't call him a lot of mean -- maybe.

CASONE: Yes, I think he's -- I think he's a little on a defensive.

MCDOWELL: The child deserves all the foul balls. How about that, though?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, some final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Bell, Lee Carter, quick final thoughts. Five seconds.

SPICER: I'm glad to be here to kick off the briefing. Thanks for having me.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, take it away, Sir.

VARNEY: I'm surprised at Sean Spicer. I thought he got more to him than that one. He had at least five seconds to spare there.

(LAUGHTER)

SPICER: I yield it to you, Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, you're a good man.

END
