urn:contentItem:5SW9-WRF1-DY0W-40T9-00000-00Trump Tweets Explosive Threat To Iran President Rouhani; Sergio Marchionne, Auto Legend, Steps Down As Ceo Of Fiat Chrysler2018-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisTrump Tweets Explosive Threat To Iran President Rouhani; Sergio Marchionne, Auto Legend, Steps Down As Ceo Of FiatChryslerLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern. Earnings in focus, it will be the busiest week for the second quarter reporting season. One-third of the Dow Industrials and S&P 500 set to post results this week. We look at what he numbers and guidance about the state -- the United States economy. We get the reading -- the first reading on second quarter on gross domestic product -- economic growth on Friday.

Look at these futures right here right now. Three-point gain on the Dow futures. Markets searching for direction after the Dow and S&P managed to eke out small gains last week. Although that was your Friday close, it was some small across the board on Friday.

And then moving on, let's check on Europe. We have declines across the board. But contained the biggest loser the CAC Quarante in France down half about half of one percent right now. In Asia overnight, it was mixed markets, the Shanghai Composite and Hang Seng heading higher, the Nikkei and KOSPI in South Korea suffering losses.

Tragedy in Toronto, the death toll rising in last night's deadly shooting rampage. A gunman killing at least two and injuring a dozen others.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard at least 20 shots in intervals, you know, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent. I saw at least four people shot here by the fountain.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is a street where people walk every day to go to the groceries to have dinner, to have an ice cream, sit in the square, enjoy their summer. And it is absolutely devastating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest as authorities work to find a motive. War of words. President Trump threatening Iran with severe consequences if that nation does not take a cautious tone with the United States. And unexpected change at the top of FiatChrysler. The automaker replacing CEO Sergio Marchionne after he suffered complications from recent surgery. What the change means for the future of the company.

Making a private call with a superhero twist. One company creating a private cubicle with a Superman theme. For the first time in decades, oh, EPA chief Scott Pruitt now gone, could have gotten that phone booths in his office instead of the one that he's had taxpayer for. All of that and so much more coming up this morning. CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell.

Look who it is, former White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer.

SEAN SPICER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Good morning.

MCDOWELL: And Lee Carter, the President of Maslansky and Partners. Sean Spicer has a new book. There you go. We'll talk about it.

SPICER: And you've got a copy of it.

MCDOWELL: Yes. It's not signed. I don't know what's wrong (INAUDIBLE)

SPICER: It will be. It will be signed.

MCDOWELL: It called a briefing. We're going to talk about to Sean about it. Coming up, politics to press and the President. And maybe the President will tweet some this hour and we can get your instantaneous response.

SPICER: Probability is high.

MCDOWELL: All right. He's already been tweeting this morning. So, Mr. President, let's ramp that up to our top story this hour on trade with China. President Trump will host a White House event showcasing American products from all 50 states today following his threats to impose tariffs on all exports out of China and to the U.S. We're talking more than $500 billion worth of annual imports.

Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin amplifying the threats saying he "would -- he wouldn't minimize" the chance of this actually happening. And adding that. If Europe believes in free trade, the U.S. is ready for a deal. Joining me now is Ohio Congressman, Jim Renacci. A member of the House Ways and Means Committee, House Budget Committee. Congressman, first did I pronounce your name correctly?

REP. JIM RENACCI (R), OHIO: You did. Renacci, that's right.

MCDOWELL: All right. So what is your take on President Trump's trade threats and have you heard concerns from your constituents?

RENACCI: Well, it's a mixed bag. As I talk talked to my constituents they always say to me, look, we're a little concerned but we want you supporting the President. And it's interesting I've had everybody from soybeans, you know, the agriculture industry into my office to manufactures. Just last week and I always say to him, what do you want me to tell President because I have opportunity to sit with him and what would you rather mew saying?

They go, well, we're concerned but we want to you support him. We want you -- we realize, you know, we have to go through this process. It's amazing because you can't get a straight answer even soybean manufacturer, the growers, I said to them, now seriously, tell me because they come in and they say they're concerned. I said, so what -- so what would your -- if you had a chance to sit down with him what would you say?

MCDOWELL: But their business is being hurt though because they -- because the concern but once people start feeling a real world impact on their livelihoods, it might be different, right?

RENACCI: Well, they are feeling it, they told me they're feeling it but they also understand the need to be able to go through this. They understand the President's negotiating. That's what I tell them. We're in a negotiations phase, let's get through these negotiations. I've had an opportunity to sit with the President car where he says, look, I'm worried about children and grandchildren.

And at some point in time, you know, we need to make sure that we're working through this and give me some time and that's what I tell them.

SPICER: How much time do you think that will give him?

RENACCI: You know, it's going to be interesting. I say that I asked that question too last week and they said -- I said, how much time do you want to give them? And they said, well, let's look at, you know, four, five, six months and we where we're at. So that's ---

SPICER: Because it feels like if you don't do anything, they suffer the consequences of Chinese economic policies. But if you do something that's some short-term pain and I think that's where -- trying to figure out where that balance is.

RENACCI: Well, I was telling them short-term pain, a long-term gain. I mean, that's like --

(CROSSTALK)

SPICER: Right.

RENACCI: And that's like anything else. We have to go be willing to do that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: When you were -- we were just talking to Gordon earlier and he was saying, this isn't going to be short- term pain, this could be 10, 20 years, it's a long game the way that the Chinese play.

RENACCI: Well, and the truth of it is, we have a long game already because the Chinese have been doing this to us for so many years. So now it's time to go through this process. And look, the most powerful message I heard from the President one time was when he said to me, I don't want our children and grandchildren on their knees begging in the future. We have to be willing to work through this.

BELL: Well, I think you saw that in the poll -- the Wall Street Journal poll that came out that people aren't necessarily happy with how he's dealing with trade but his overall rating is going up because I think that the stock market and also, you know, manufacturers, soybean growers and the like, the whole country thinks that this is a negotiating tactic and it's going to end well, but the problem is when does it end?

CARTER: Yes. I think it's also really, really important point though to say can you can be both be concerned and want to support the President at the same time. And I think that a lot of people have missed that because, you think that if you support a President you support him blindly. And I don't think that's the truth. I think most people -- for a lot of people somewhere in the middle depending on the issue.

SPICER: Well, I think that people have been told for a long time that policies going to change and they finally see the President fighting for them willing and they're willing to give them a little bit of latitude to see where this thing ends up.

MCDOWELL: Listen, I have been from breathe one, very concerned about these tariffs that have been slapped on starting with washing machines but then particularly steel and aluminum tariffs and the retaliation that we've gotten from some of our trading but most important trading partners and allies. But the messaging, I want to hit on this, because the messaging from day one when Peter Navarro was on this program quizzing me.

When I wasn't on set about how much is a cost of six pack of beer going to go up. And the Wall Street Journal wrote an editorial last week saying Peter Navarro says the harm is a rounding error and their take was -- well, he is out of touch because there are a number of -- there is a pipeline builder down in Texas that wanted a steel -- a waiver from the steel -- wanted a steel tariff exemption in other company -- another pipeline producer as well.

They didn't get them. And it's going to cost -- it's going to hurt because they're going to delay investment in --

(CROSSTALK)

SPICER: -- construction industry as well in term of the cost of whether it's a beam or a screw. Things are starting to go up and that's costing people money. The question I think that we're just asking the Congressman is how long and how long will tolerate. They want the fight, they've seen Chinese economic policies, adversely affect our economy, our workers too long and they're willing to give the President I think some latitude for a while.

But the question is going to be how long.

RENACCI: Well, I say the same thing but I always tell them let's judge this President. You get a chance to a judge the President in a couple more years in election. So let's judge him then, let's not judge him today. Let's let them go through negotiations.

MCDOWELL: But you guys, well, people go to the polls to reelect you or not come November and on that note let's talk about tax cuts 2.0 which the House is working on, revitalizing the economy, the second round, a big part of the GOP's plan to try and retain control of the House. Here is what House Majority Whip Steve Scalise told Maria yesterday morning on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA), HOUSE MAJORITY WHIP: The plans to continue focusing on getting the economy moving, seeing this great economic growth, and then locking it in. We're going to bring some more bills to cut taxes, we're going to make the tax cuts permanent. That bill Chairman Brady, his committee are already working on. We just did a jobs 3.0 bill.

A bill to provide more regulatory relief and do some things that will help create more jobs and rebuild the middle class.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Is it enough for you as people head to the polls if the House passed that? And the Senate already showing resistance to it.

RENACCI: Well, I can tell you in Ohio, tax 1.0 is working. Companies are now reinvesting, I had a company went from 70 to 140 employees already. I have companies who are talking about expanding. They're also giving bonuses out to their employees, they're raising wages. So as I travel, Ohio people are very happy. Now, if we can lock that in which is important because the only reason it's not locked in its gimmicks in Washington.

I mean, I'm a business guy. I always chuckle at some of these little gimmicks we have. We couldn't lock in it because of this rule or that rule. So let's lock it in, let's make sure people have certainty and predictability. I think that's going to be the second thing. And also on 2.0, we're going to be talking about savings. So I think that's another issue. These -- a lot of people back in Ohio are now getting more money in their pockets.

We need to make sure they can save it and use it for their -- whether it's education, whatever. So those -- that's what 2.0 is going to be all about. I think it's -- can be best explained that way when I travel the state.

SPICER: I think the other thing is -- I mean, look, elections are binary choice and it's not just what Jim Renacci is for, it's what Sherrod Brown isn't for. And that's a thing -- it's a big contrast that Ohio voters are going to face. It's not just are you going to keep more, we're going talk about economic expansion, it's what Sherrod Brown isn't going to do to help Ohio businesses and families. I mean, that's pretty much.

RENACCI: Well, that's true too. And I mean, it's polar total opposites because I'm running against somebody who didn't support the tax cuts bill.

MCDOWELL: Not one Democrat voted for the tax cut so -- but then they were upset. You heard this from Nancy Pelosi but then they're upset that the individual tax cuts weren't permanent and they keep -- or they're now worried about the debt and the deficit all of a sudden, so which is it? And you don't get -- you don't get to say because she didn't vote.

RENACCI: Right. And, again, here is the issue for me. I came here as a businessman and now I look at the numbers, 85 percent of our deficit or things unrelated to the tax cut and the tax cut actually if it grows the economy which it's doing and we get sustained growth over three percent, then it will pay for itself and it will grow the economy and it will pay the debt down. So that's the key.

MCDOWELL: Speaking of which, we're going to get the first reading on second quarter growth. And the -- it's going to be likely north of four percent. The Wall Street Journal estimate is 4.2, the GDP now from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank is 4-1/2, they're whisperer is coming out of White House, it's going to be north 4-1/2. But again, does that stick with people. Does that -- the number resonate or are they already feeling that?

BELL: I think they're feeling it. We've discussed it earlier in the show, the consumers, the everyday people, working class people are out there feeling the benefits in their paychecks, they're feeling better but, you know, we have the most jobs available out there with the lowest jobless rate that we've seen in almost 20 years. The consumers feeling good, confidence remains high so --

MCDOWELL: And you see that in this Wall Street Journal NBC News poll that found half of registered voters approve of the President handling of the economy. His highest mark on that question in the survey. That same poll found that President's approval rating edged higher even during the week, Lee Carter, when he came under criticism for his handling of that Helsinki Summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The President's approval rating rose to 45 percent. That is the highest of his presidency.

CARTER: It is. And there's two reasons why. I think number one, we can't forget the importance of the Supreme Court to voters out there. I think Republicans will support the President almost no matter what because that is so, so, so important to them. And the other thing is, I think Democrats really blew it big in the way that they responded to Helsinki and the President's comments.

Because well, a lot of people were rightfully upset by what the President did say. He later tried to correct himself. I think that the hysteria that happened over that actually made people more likely defend the President that anything else. So the Democrats really think and the media really needs to learn how to balance their coverage and say, well, we might be concerned, we don't have to get hysterical over it if they won't make any moves here.

It's also important to know though that even though these are -- these are pretty high rates, this isn't necessarily significant in that other presidents have had higher approval ratings at the same point, but I think it's telling.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, Congressman, but we have -- potentially Vladimir Putin coming to the United States for another summit right before people go to the polls in November. Are you concerned about that?

RENACCI: Not at all. I think this is -- again, the President has to be able to negotiate even with some of the people that are enemies of us and I think that's the key. So we will continue to go and as we said, this confidence is going to continue to build. I want to go back whether you're firefighter or police, your 401(k)s and your pensions are going up and that's positive.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE) thank you, Congressman Renacci. Still to come, an unexpected leadership shake-up at FiatChrysler. The details are the automaker's longtime CEO is stepping down due to health issues. Plus, Hasbro and Halliburton reporting quarterly earnings this morning. We break down those numbers.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Nicole Petallides live on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow futures this morning only slightly to the downside, down six of the Dow Jones Industrial average. And it's earning season, the big, big week here, 170 S & 500 companies coming out with numbers.

We'll kick it off with two that have reported this morning including Halliburton and Hasbro. So Halliburton is looking to downside to the tune of about to 1.1 percent while Hasbro is jumping 10percent. The Halliburton in particular, it was in line earnings per share, that's why you're seeing a little bit of selling, everybody is getting so used to be so far this season. The estimates were 20.5 percent growth year-over-year for earnings.

And in fact, we've seen most of these companies beating, so we've seen over 21percent but Halliburton did have quarterly revenue on the rise, higher oil prices and more rigs at work. Hasbro as I noted up 10-1/2 percent there, topping and soaring as it handily beat those analysts' estimates for profit and sales by a wide margin.

At then we'll watch for Alphabet, Google after the bell today. That will be key, not only will they watch for consistent revenue gains but also some of those other areas, apps, pixel smartphones, licensing also cloud computing stock just down a quarter of one percent right now. So keep it right here because coming up, former FBI Director James Comey is getting political once again.

Why he is urging Democrats to not lose their minds and rush to the socialist left. It's all ahead. Plus, spice up your office space. Details on the new cubicle inspired by Superman that costs over $8,000. That is all later this hour. Keep it right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. Let's kick off this new week with slightly lower futures, five -- four-point loss on the Dow futures right now. But again, the direction this week will be decided by earnings. Alphabet, the parent of Google, Facebook, Amazon, and Twitter all set to report quarterly results this week. Alphabet kicks things off after the close today. The Google parent company reporting after the bell.

Joining is now beyond sport global ambassador, Fox News contributor, my dear friend, John Layfield. John, your expectation for earnings going into this week?

JOHN LAYFIELD, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think we have another great earning season. The last earnings season that we had was the best earnings beat in 25 years since the early 1990s. We're seeing so far a third of S&P 500 companies reported, 87 percent have had earnings expectations that had an upside on those earnings, the estimates that they've had. So it's going to be interesting to see what we're going to see these earnings.

Especially when you have automakers reporting this week. We have G.M. and Ford which I own both reporting. They've already have commodity inflation problems. So interesting to see how whether hedge for these tariffs going forward and how these tariffs are going to affect projections going forward.

MCDOWELL: Lindsey, some other companies to watch are these industrial companies. I think Whirlpool, Harley-Davidson or two of the names out with earnings this week. We will be listening for those even 3M listening for the impact of the steel and aluminum tariffs. And any kind of supply chain disruption these companies are experiencing.

BELL: Absolutely. We're seeing these companies, 94 percent of the industrial companies that have reported have beat on both the top and the bottom line. The stocks are reacting really well, the question, John, is I don't know if you have a thought on this, it feels like the question is, is -- are orders being pulled forward? Is the second quarter coming in significantly better than expected?

Because people are trying to get ahead of tariffs and that's what's causing raised guidance for full year or are we just doing better than we thought?

LAYFIELD: That's a great question, Lindsey. And it's a little bit of both. We are seeing earnings pulled forward, people getting around these tariffs. So you're seeing lot of stuff shift early because of this, but you are seeing better-than-expected. We're going to have a -- look like a four percent GDP. That's going to be a little inflated because people are getting these orders out there ahead of these tariffs.

The earnings season this year, I mean, this is the dichotomy of this administration. We're going to have 20 percent earnings a gain this quarter. About 35 to 40 percent of that comes from these tax cuts. So the administration has done a great job in spurring this economy that is already long in the tooth in this bull market to revitalization. The problem is all 100 percent. Now black cloud is these tariffs.

And what can happen if the potential trade war happens. It could negate everything that happens with these tax cuts.

MCDOWELL: But so far, John, it looks like the markets are giving the White House, giving administration some breathing room on how long do you think that can last? I mean to your point, we're going to get guidance this week from some major industrial companies, the automakers about any potential fallout?

LAYFIELD: I think it starts until it starts significantly hurting, you know, it's easy when you talk about a potential trade war. We're actually in a trade war right now no matter what level of that trade war we're in, we're actually in one right now. You look at Tampa Bay, Pittsburgh, Salt Lake, they're all reducing headcount right now in their newspaper business because of the tariffs that we have on Canadian paper.

So you're starting to see problems right now, you see soybeans, you see livestock right now, you see a glut of that going on because we have two problems. We had a huge amount of livestock produced this year and we also have these tariffs that are coming also. We have a glut. Until you start seeing these -- Americans start being hurt which I think we're going to start seeing, I think you give the President a pass on this, this is negotiations.

But this is sticking and matched next to (INAUDIBLE) and say, hey, I'm going to blow up everything if you don't agree. It is a dangerous, dangerous game we're playing right now.

MCDOWELL: John, how do you structure portfolio around that? Because again you're not getting paid that much to own fixed income here. How do you allocate money?

LAYFIELD: I think dividend stocks become to de facto bonds like they had been for the past several years. I know interest rates are rising but that's still a play. Look, you have problems in the E.U. If Englands are upset of the E.U., which it looks like they're probably going to do with probably a hard Brexit, that takes out a huge amount of fees going to E.U. The E.U. looks like it could break up especially we started losing smaller parts like Italy and somebody else follows.

You look at the problems in China right now, the U.S. stock market is still the place to be and I think dividend stocks are going to be the safe play going forward because I don't think people know what's going to happen with this market. This market should be significantly higher. This economy is absolutely on fire. The only black cloud right now is the trade tariffs and that's why I will stay with dividend stocks.

MCDOWELL: Well, I'll say this ahead of the head of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker is going to be at the White House on Wednesday, maybe you get some positive developments out of that meeting? You never know.

LAYFIELD: He doesn't have high expectations according to people around him but you're right, we could have something, a big upside surprise come out of that. I wouldn't be surprised if the E.U. says, you know, we're just going to drop the 10 percent tariffs on cars and then see what the President does because it's really about those tariffs then the President will drop it and this trade war could end at least with our friends here.

The problem we have with Europe right now is they're now negotiations deals with our trading partners that are our neighbors in Canada and Mexico. This could be long-term structural damage if we don't get in front of this right now and try to work out something with Mr. Juncker when he visits this week.

MCDOWELL: Right. That tariff that we have on light trucks that are imported, it's a 25 percent tariff, it's called the chicken tax among people I grew up with because it was retaliation to this fight we had with Europe over poultry in 1964 I think. So, you think tariffs can't hang around? That one has been around since before I was born. Thank you, John. And before you were born too, I should point out. John Layfield.

LAYFIELD: Correct.

MCDOWELL: Always great to see you, my friend. Coming up. Escalating tensions with Iran. The new warning from President Trump after Iran's leader says any conflict with the country would lead to the mother of all wars. Plus, a surprise shake-up at FiatChrysler. Details on the unexpected changes after the automaker's long-time CEO steps down ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 23rd, your top stories at 8:30 a.m. Eastern. One big week for earnings, one-third of the Dow Industrials and S&P 500 reporting, this week, Facebook, Twitter, Amazon, all on deck.

This afternoon's big reveal will be from Alphabet, the parent company of Google. Take a look at how the stock is premarket. Let's take a look at the Futures across the board, the Dow and S&P did manage to eke out small gains last week, and they're up to -- they are in the green right now.

The NASDAQ, 100, the Futures there are lower as the NASDAQ was, last week, slipping. In Europe, markets are headed lower this morning as well, losses across the board. The CAC Quarante in France, the biggest loser down half of one percent.

The Asian markets finishing mixed, the Nikkei ending down more than one percent, one and a third percent, to be exact, the KOSPI in South Korea also losing almost nine-tenth of one percent.

President Trump tweeting out to the president of Iran last night, with a firm warning, saying not to threaten the U.S. or else, and former FBI Director James Comey, cautioning the Dems on twitter. He says, don't vote for whatever socialist -- Democratic socialist, whatever they are calling today.

FiatChrysler stock almost three percent in the red in premarket trading on the sudden replacement of the company's well-known CEO, Sergio Marchionne, over the weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SUPERMAN: This is a job for Superman.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: And in celebration of Superman's 88th birthday, one company's got a box for you. Now, all is a Superman themed cubicle, modelled after the same telephone booth that the Man of Steel used to get changed in, with a few modern perks, red cape, not included.

To our top story this half hour, President Trump giving a stern warning to Iran, escalating a war of words with the country's leader, Kristina Partsinevelos is live at the White House with the very latest. Good morning, Kristina.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. And you are right, the escalation has continued, the rhetoric between both countries Iran and United States, why is this happening, why is the President tweeting in all caps?

This comes after the president of Iran gave a speech on Sunday to his population, and he said, that if any conflict bn between the United States and Iran, occurs, then it would be the mother of all wars.

President Trump took to twitter yesterday, in all capitals, when in the online world, essentially means yelling, he wrote, never, ever threaten United States again, or you will suffer consequences the likes of when few throughout history have ever suffered before. We are no longer a country that will stand for your demented words or violence and death. Be cautious.

And when I say the rhetoric has continued to escalate, you know that the United States has pulled out of Iran nuclear deal in 20 -- or 2015 Iran nuclear deal in May. Just last month, the United States said that they were going to impose sanctions against any exports leaving Iran.

This comes at a time when the country in Iran is suffering. The economy is not doing so well and that had a huge effect on the price of oil. Today, we're seeing a trade just around $68.92. But over the past two months, you've seen it fluctuate quite a bit and climb higher because of the lack of supply around the globe, especially coming from Iran.

Iran has retaliated saying that they too will block any type of shipments coming out of there. But so far, it's just back and forth rhetoric between the two countries. And it's only Monday morning, 8:00 a.m. and we're getting all this news. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Kristina, thank you for delivering it to us, Kristina Partsinevelos, at the White House for us. Sean, I want to get your reaction to the President's tweet, especially since it seems to be one of the --you know, message control is the most impossible thing to do.

They're in the White House, because again, that's the President, tweeting out.

SPICER: I mean, the beauty is everyone knows talks about transparency. I mean, you are hearing directly from him what he thinks, when he tweets like this.

And if I were President Rouhani, I would take caution in making some of those outlandish statements, threatening United States, because I think this president doesn't like to be looked at like that and he will take swift indecisive action.

So, Rouhani may forget that we can all hear what he says, when he does it in the modern world, but that was a mistake on his part.

MCDOWELL: Iran was still firing, firing missiles after the Iran nuclear deal was done with death to America, death to Israel.

SPICER: And I don't think this President -- this President-- you know, Kristina mentioned it, but he -- this -- the Iran nuclear deal is something that is he is consistently talked about being a bad deal, and if Iran ups the game, he is going to do something.

MCDOWELL: Right. And now, Europe has to come to us to get -- basically get waivers from sanctions that we are preparing to impose on Iran.

The President tweeted again, this morning, on Russia, when you hear the fake news talking negatively about my meeting with President Putin, and all that I gave up, remember, I gave up nothing, we merely talked about future benefits for both countries. Also, we got along very well, which is a good thing, except for the corrupt media.

MCDOWELL: Sean, your take on that? Again, the fact that it was discussed that the likes of Michael McFaul, the former ambassador to Russia, that Putin says to our President, why I want to interview these Americans. The fact that that even came up was bothersome to many.

SPICER: Well, but, again, I don't -- part of what we don't know is what exactly was said, the context it was said, and what Trump did or did not respond. I think the White House has made it very clear that the idea that Russia would interrogate any United States citizen, never mind the former ambassador, is fairly laughable.

And I think it's good that they clarified these kinds of things because it's not -- I mean, the idea that a former government official would be interrogated by any country, never mind Russia in Putin, is something that we should be very clear about what our nation's position is.

MCDOWELL: If Putin -- assuming that Putin does come to the United States right before the midterm elections and there was a second summit on U.S. soil, be sure that there will be people in that tete-a-tete.

SPICER: Well, I think the President is seeing the reaction that he saw walking out of that summit. I think they're going to come in to any kind of future summit with their A game.

CARTER: Do you think that --

MCDOWELL: So, you are saying that wasn't the President's A game?

SPICER: No, I think that they -- after meeting with Kim, I think they looked at the model and they were -- there was largely a lot of praise coming from that, how the President had handled that meeting, how the reaction had been in terms of him engaging with Kim, talking about denuclearization in the peninsula.

And I think that this Helsinki summit seemed to follow a very similar pattern. I don't think that they fully appreciated the reaction that Putin would get, versus Kim.

CARTER: I also think the President didn't help himself with some of the statements that he made, following, right? Where he was almost -- seemed like he was (INAUDIBLE) more with Russia than --

SPICER: Sure. And I think it's a good thing that they went out and clarified.

CARTER: Now, how do you think -- what do you think about his clarification? Do you think that was enough? Do you think people buy it?

SPICER: You know, so far, it seems like they do, I think it's important. I mean, look, he has been -- it's good that he clarified it. And, you know, I -- talk -- there is an intensity to this White House of how they cover it -- how they cover this president unlike ever before.

MCDOWELL: The (INAUDIBLE) and the media.

SPICER: The media. And that's why I wrote a book that literally goes through a lot of these big moments and how -- thank you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I'm holding - I was going to ask you about this.

SPICER: OK. What I mean, I think that there is a level of intensity in scrutiny that in past administrations, they haven't had to face.

MCDOWELL: True. But it's called the briefing politics, the press and the President. I would say, you put the words, the press, on the front cover of a book, that doesn't really help sales, my friend.

SPICER: Well, I will --

MCDOWELL: People hate the --

SPICER: But I think part of what people want to know is, what is it really like inside? And that's the thing. You see one thing on television. You get to see us sitting here at the table. What's going on behind-the- scenes?

And part of the reason that I wrote the book is that the press gets to have their say. They get to put in paper, or put on television what they want you to see, what they want you to read. What I wanted to do is take readers behind-the-scenes and say, this is what's actually happening when - - that you don't see.

MCDOWELL: But -- is it safe to say that this is a President, this is a man, the leader of the country who if you are trying to craft a message, you can't control the message, because he is going to say what he wants to say, and you are more crisis response or just a respond --

SPICER: I was going to say -- I wouldn't say no, because -- I mean, right, I think you are clearly in response, he is the leader.

And that is a very different role than I normally played many -- most press people where your job is to craft and execute a message and a plan. This president leads the way in every one of those fronts.

MCDOWELL: There hasn't been any lasting fallout for the President or even the White House. I would argue for anything that on Twitter. And even --

SPICER: No, in fact, I wouldn't. But that's probably why one of the reasons he won. I mean, he has been -- and I write about all of these instances were any other political candidate would have been left for dead. I mean, I guarantee you, if a candidate for office went to Lee and said, poll what I just did.

It would come back and say, you're dead. Get out of the race. And what this President, every time, not only picked himself up, but in most cases, came up stronger.

CARTER: And it's part of -- I mean, it is part of who he is, right? I think people wanted somebody who is going to go down, shape things up and do things differently than it's ever been before. And so the fact that he does this and continues to do it, I think, just reinforces that message.

MCDOWELL: I want to get to Jim Comey, yes, Jim Comey, the midterm elections, three months away, Former FBI Director, Comey, issuing a warning to Democrats.

He tweeted this, yesterday, Democrats, please, please don't lose your minds and rush to the socialist left. This president and his Republican Party are counting on you to do exactly that. America's great middle wants sensible, balanced, ethical leadership.

But where is the sensible balanced ethical candidate who's running for the Democrat?

SPICER: Well, his tweet's a little too late. I mean, that run to the left, already happened. So, he's a little late on his tweet. I mean, that's the problem. They are now having a -- they're tripping over themselves, to go further and further to the left.

They are not progressives. I mean, they are now like Bernie Sanders, was a socialist running for president and was -- at one point, viewed as the extreme. He's now become the mainstream of the Democratic Party, and you have to go further and further to the left, to get traction.

CARTER: You know, I just wonder, though, I can't -- I look at all of this and I think I don't necessarily believe that it's a whole of the Democrats that are going left. I think that it's a socialists, the far left, it's the only part of the party that has a message that resonates to people because they are talking about things that matter most.

MCDOWELL: They're lying to the American people.

CARTER: Whether or not --

MCDOWELL: I know that they're absolutely lying.

CARTER: They're saying something besides resist.

SPICER: To your point, I mean, you can talk about all of these things at some point. They never tell you about the price tag. They never talk about the economic consequences that these policies would have on our economy.

Walking around and telling everyone that everything is going to be free, is a great message. But the reality is, it's unsustainable, and it is not something that is a direction in our country that we have been against for a long time. We have been against socialism and against a lot of this stuff.

And now, we're talking about -- in the other day, they talked about the minimum income -- you know, were people will be given a -- like, that's insane. The idea we should be talking about is how do we create an economy that allows people to have the opportunities that they need, how do we provide a social safety net.

But the idea that we're talking about guaranteeing everybody all of this free stuff, is unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, in your book, you don't believe, as the President suggested that most media is the enemy of the state.

SPICER: No. I wrote about it. I actually write that there are a lot of good reporters, and that we need in a democracy a robust and active press corps, that's essential to our democracy. But what we need to do is know where the line is. Call out bad reporters and bad stories and also praise good reports and good stories.

And it is not about being tough that reporters should be in pursuit of the truth. They should write tough, tough stories.

MCDOWELL: Right.

SPICER: But they should be called out when they are wrong.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And cut out the rehearsed hysteria, right, the rehearsed sneering. Coming up, legend in the auto industry, stepping down. The surprise leadership shake-up after FiatChrysler CEO resigned. Plus, earning season in full swing, Stuart Varney weighs in, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A busy week in the world of Wall Street. No, America! Tech -- big tech companies: Alphabet, that's parent of Google, Facebook, reporting earnings this week. Also, we get the first reading on how fast the economy was growing during the second quarter. Everybody is watching it, especially, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. I love it when you talk earnings and economic numbers because I know that that's --

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, you don't. You don't. You hate it.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I do. Actually, I love it because --

VARNEY: I don't know what I'm talking about when it comes to earnings --

MCDOWELL: That's not true. Again, who held onto his Microsoft stock? You. What stock hit an all-time high on Friday? Microsoft. There you go.

VARNEY: I had nothing to do with earnings per share. I couldn't tell you. Or, QE3 or anything else, and believe me, it didn't. Look, I think this is a pivotal week. The stuff going on this week which would make an enormous difference to your money. As you said, Dagen, first of all, you got the earnings from big tech, it's a big week for big tech. Here they come, we're going to find out how much money they've made and how much they expect to make in the future. That will have a significant impact on those stocks, big tech stocks, which have been leading this market for at least a couple of years. Then, we've got the GDP numbers, that's Friday morning, 8:30 Eastern Time. I know you will be covering it and so will we. I'm expecting around four percent growth per year, annualized growth, four percent.

Now, that would be a blockbuster news item because we've never achieved that rate of growth in the last four -- I think it's been four years since we had a four percent quarter. And then, don't forget, Wednesday, we have the Europeans coming over here, top-level delegation coming over to the White House. They're talking trade. There's the possibility of a breakthrough right there. Either that or a breakdown, one of the two, and that again makes this a very pivotal week. So, I'm glad everybody is tuning in, it's worthwhile.

MCDOWELL: What if we get -- and so much -- I've talked till I'm blue in the face about these potential tariffs on automobile imports and how that would hurt U.S. carmakers and any carmaker abroad or here at home, so many of the foreign automakers have plants here, produce most of the cars that they sell here, in fact. But Stuart, what if we do get a breakthrough, what if we do have, hey, we're just going to get rid of all of the auto tariffs between Europe and the United States? We're safe in the next three years. What if that happens, it would be incredible?

VARNEY: Huge for the markets.

MCDOWELL: Right.

VARNEY: I think the summer rally has been held back by all those negative trade headlines. It's not being pushed down so much as held back I would say. But if you get a breakthrough Wednesday, and they come out with at least a lessening of the tension, an agreement in some form or other to just maybe get rid of some tariffs, that I think would be absolutely huge, that would really set the stage for a big rally.

MCDOWELL: I think about this every morning when I get up. That is the danger of always being negative and --

VARNEY: Wait a minute, wait a minute. The first thing you think of when you wake up in the morning, is, oh, the Europeans are coming to a trade deal. I don't believe it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, being positive and making sure that you don't look at everything through a negative lens because again, then you miss all the good stuff.

VARNEY: That's the whole point about the Trump presidency, isn't it? Think positive. He's winning, the economy is expanding, we've got prosperity coming at us. You know, think positive, that's why the market is up so much.

MCDOWELL: And even with some mean tweets, that's why his approval ratings are up, too. Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: True. Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, he starts in 10 minutes every day, 9:00 a.m. to noon. Coming up, a phone booth worthy of Superman. Details on the new office cubicle that will cost you over $8,000, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The death toll rising in last night's mass shooting in Toronto. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Dagen, we just got an update from police. A second victim has died from the rampage, a gunman shot 14 people including a young girl in Toronto. The 29-year-old suspect's body was later found at the scene, but it's not clear at this point whether the man actually killed himself or he was shot by police. All of this happened in the Toronto neighborhood known as Greektown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would say I heard at least 20 shots in intervals. You know, clippings spent, reloading, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent, that's what I heard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, investigators are trying to find a motive. Police say they would not rule out, at this point, terrorism.

Well, tragedy in Maryland overnight after a firefighter died while battling a massive seven alarm blaze. The unidentified firefighter, a 13-year veteran fell through the floor. Three people who were inside the house were able to get out, though, in time. The cause of the fire under investigation, but lightning could be the cause.

Well, some stunning news over the weekend at a change at the top for FiatChrysler. Long-time CEO Sergio Marchionne has been replaced. Marchionne underwent shoulder surgery three weeks ago but in those three weeks, his condition has somehow worsened. We're looking for more details. Now, Mike Manley, who runs the Jeep, SUV, and Ram truck division is the new CEO. While the stock is something to watch today, shares are actually lower in the premarket, it's down more than three percent right now. Again, stunning news over the weekend for this company.

Well, a Superman solution for workers who want more privacy, for the first time in 80 years, the Superman cubicle booth is available for purchase. It fits two people inside -- if that makes sense -- it comes with modern necessities like USB outlets and an Ethernet connection, LED lights. You're going to have to make more money than Clark Kent, though, it's actually running about $8500 per booth. And by the way, in the description it doesn't mention to actually having a phone. I don't think people use those anymore, all right.

And then, finally, there is this, we've been watching this clip over and over again this morning on the show. It appears to show a grown man stealing a foul ball from a child. Well, the Chicago Cubs saw the situation play out in real-time. They ended up giving the young boy an autographed baseball instead. But it turns out the man that everybody is criticizing had helped that boy get a foul ball earlier in the game. You can see him holding a game-used baseball next to his new autographed one, obviously. Yes. So, maybe the guy in the clip isn't as mean as we all think, and we're all beating up on him this morning. So, I wanted to, you know, give you some new details on this developing story in baseball. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Glad I didn't call him a lot of mean -- maybe.

CASONE: Yes, I think he's -- I think he's a little on a defensive.

MCDOWELL: The child deserves all the foul balls. How about that, though?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, some final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Bell, Lee Carter, quick final thoughts. Five seconds.

SPICER: I'm glad to be here to kick off the briefing. Thanks for having me.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, take it away, Sir.

VARNEY: I'm surprised at Sean Spicer. I thought he got more to him than that one. He had at least five seconds to spare there.

(LAUGHTER)

SPICER: I yield it to you, Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, you're a good man.

END
