Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKD-KV31-JB20-G52C-00000-00Trump Versus "The Squad"; Biden Versus Sanders on Health Care; E.U. Leader Scramble to Save Iran Nuclear Deal; Man Confesses to Killing U.S. Scientist in Crete. Aired 4-4:30a ET2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisEARLY START4:00 AM ESTNEWSInternational071601CN.V34Trump Versus "The Squad"; Biden Versus Sanders on Health Care; E.U. Leader Scramble to Save Iran Nuclear Deal; Man Confesses to Killing U.S. Scientist in Crete. Aired 4-4:30a ETDave Briggs, Jessica Dean, Arwa Damon

President Trump escalating the ugliest of ugly politics; instead of apologizing for his racist attack on four progressive House members, he justified it at a White House news conference. Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders square off on health care, a pivotal issue now dividing some Democrats. European leaders say Iran's breach of the nuclear deal is not significant as they scrambled to save the deal from collapse, but Iran's former minister says Tehran is not prepared to renegotiate. A 27-year-old man has confessed to killing American scientist Suzanne Eaton on the Greek island of Crete.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

[04:00:18] DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As far as I'm concerned, if you hate our country, if you're not happy here, you can leave.

REP. ILHAN OMAR (D-MN): This is the agenda of white nationalists.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DAVE BRIGGS, CNN ANCHOR: The defense of racism now an ironclad part of the president's playbook. His rhetoric met with mild criticism from the Republican Party he has reshaped.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The transition of dropping 300 million people on a new plan are a little risky.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The system that Joe and others are trying to prop up is the most wasteful bureaucratic and expensive system on earth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JESSICA DEAN, CNN ANCHOR: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders square off on health care, a pivotal issue now dividing some Democrats.

BRIGGS: Joy and relief after a missing hiker is rescued in California. Sheryl Powell went missing for four days. Her family says she was hiding from an attacker.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEPUTY WILL KIMBRO, BERKELEY COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE, BERKELEY COUNTY, SOUTH CAROLINA: There we go. There we go. Come on. Come on, baby. She's breathing. As long as she's crying like that, she's breathing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: A heart-pumping rescue in South Carolina. A deputy pulls over a car for speeding and saves a baby in distress. Good morning. Welcome to our viewers in the United States and all around the world. This is EARLY START and I'm Jessica Dean, in for Christine Romans.

BRIGGS: Good morning.

DEAN: Good morning.

BRIGGS: The summer of Romans continues.

I'm Dave Briggs, Tuesday, July 16. It is 4:00 a.m. here in New York, 9:00 a.m. in London, 11:00 a.m. in Istanbul.

We begin this morning with President Trump escalating the ugliest of ugly politics. Instead of apologizing for his racist attack on four progressive House members, he justified it at a White House news conference. Trump sparked the controversy Sunday when he tweeted that the congresswomen, all of them U.S. citizens, should go back where they came from.

John Roberts of Fox News put this question of the president yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Does it concern you that many people saw that tweet as racist and that white nationalist groups are finding common cause with you on that point?

TRUMP: It doesn't concern me because many people agree with me and all I'm saying, they want to leave, they can leave.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: The episode reflects the president's certainty he won't lose the support of his base nor the Republican Party he has reshaped.

DEAN: Most GOP lawmakers kept mum but a number of prominent lawmakers did come out against the remark if not against the president. Here's the only black Republican, Will Hurd of Texas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. WILL HURD (R-TX): The tweets are racist and xenophobic. They're also inaccurate. It's behavior that's unbecoming of the president of the United States and the leader of the free world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: George Conway, Washington lawyer, Trump critic and husband of Kellyanne Conway wrote a blistering op-ed for "The Washington Post".

Sunday left no doubt, Conway wrote, naivete, resentment and outright racism roiled in a toxic mix, have given us a racist president.

Now the women who Trump is painting as the America-hating communists loving face of the Republican Party are pushing back. We've got more now from White House correspondent Kaitlan Collins.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Dave and Jessica, not only is the president not backing off the remarks he made over the weekend, he's escalating his attacks on these four Democratic congresswomen, accusing them of hating the country and saying that they do not like living here, then they should leave. He was at an event on the South Lawn of the White House when he came prepared with pieces of paper with bullet points to make the case where he said he felt he was in the right.

TRUMP: As far as I'm concerned, if you hate our country, if you're not happy here, you can leave. And that's what I say all the time. That's what I said in a tweet, which I guess some people think is controversial. A lot of people love it, by the way.

COLLINS: Now, the women that the president has accused and made these attacks on held a press conference yesterday where the four of them appeared on Capitol Hill to confront what the president said, statements they said they were not surprised by to come out of the president's mouth.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY): Weak minds and leaders challenge loyalty to our country in order to avoid challenging and debating the policy.

OMAR: This is the agenda of white nationalists. Whether it is happening in chat homes or it's happening on national TV and now it's reached the White House garden.

COLLINS: I should note that Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader's office said we will hear from him at his normal press conference that he holds pretty much on a weekly basis.

[04:05:05] And people will be watching to see what it is he has to say about these racist attacks coming from the president -- Jessica and Dave.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIGGS: Kaitlan Collins there, thanks.

President Trump's racist tweets do not violate Twitter rules, so says Twitter, though that claim seems to be contradicted by the company's published policies. This is the first real test of the company's new labeling system that down ranks the tweets of the president and other world leaders that violate Twitter's guidelines. Twitter will not be participating in today's House hearing on the market power of online platforms. Representatives of Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google will be testifying.

DEAN: A fight over health care now front and center in the race for the 2020 Democratic nomination. The issue is increasing the friction between front-runner Joe Biden and challenger Bernie Sanders. The former vice president releasing a 10 year, $750 billion proposal on Monday, a plan Sanders close too wasteful and complicated.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: The system that Joe and others are trying to prop up is the most wasteful, bureaucratic and expensive system on earth. And when you talk about subsidies, what you're talking about is spending even more money, in this case taxpayer money, on a dysfunctional, wasteful and bureaucratic system. We need a simple system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: Arlette Saenz is traveling with the Biden campaign in Iowa.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ARLETTE SAENZ, CNN POLITICAL REPORTER: Dave and Jessica, Joe Biden kicked off a three-day swing through Iowa here in Des Moines by touting his newly released health care plan which he says will build on the Affordable Care Act. Now, Biden's plan would provide a public option to allow Americans to buy into a Medicare type of program. It also provides massive subsidies to make purchasing insurance through the exchanges cheaper for all-Americans regardless of income.

Biden also insisting that Medicare for All isn't the answer when it comes to health care worrying that programs like that will be difficult to implement and also are, quote, kind of a little bit risky.

REPORTER: You're talking now about a public option as part of your health care plan?

BIDEN: Yes.

REPORTER: That was very tough the last time.

BIDEN: Sure it was.

REPORTER: When Obamacare was first coming around.

BIDEN: Sure it was.

REPORTER: And it didn't happen.

BIDEN: Can you imagine what Medicare for All, if you think that's tough? Come on. Look, here's the deal, guys. One of the things that's happening is, all of a sudden, the American public has figured out what Obamacare was about.

It's solid, it's real, it's consequential. And we can in fact for a significant portion of the price, we can in fact insure 97, 98 percent of all the American people who want to be insured, and they can keep their policy if they want.

SAENZ: Now, Biden was really focused in the past week and a half on establishing clear lines of differences between himself and his Democratic opponents who are supporting a plan like Medicare for All. Now, Biden will continue promoting his health care plan over the next two days in Iowa, including making some stops in rural Iowa to talk about healthcare. We're also going to be hearing more about health care from Kamala Harris who has promised a policy proposal coming today. And Bernie Sanders will once again be making his case on Medicare for all on Wednesday.

These candidates clearly trying to draw their battle lines on health care heading into that next debate just over two weeks away -- Jessica and Dave.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIGGS: Arlette Saenz, thanks.

A check on CNN business now. Facebook wants to get into the cryptocurrency game but it's facing bipartisan resistance. Facebook unveiled its digital currency Libra last month. Since then, lawmakers have expressed skepticism that Facebook, already under attack by regulators over privacy concerns, can be trusted with a digital currency.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: To the extent that Facebook can do this correctly and can have a payment system, you know, correctly with proper AML, that's fine. They've got a lot of work to do to convince us to get to that place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Mnuchin's comments came as Facebook executive David Marcus prepares for a pair of hearings on Capitol Hill. In remarks released ahead of his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee, Marcus will say, quote, Facebook will not offer the Libra digital currency until we have fully addressed regulatory concerns and received appropriate approvals. Libra also faces resistance in the House Financial Services committee on Wednesday. Congresswoman Maxine Waters who chairs the committee has drafted legislation that could block Facebook from operating Libra.

The key big tech out of Finance Act would prohibit all large Internet companies from affiliating with or becoming financial institutions. Libra is expected to launch in early 2020.

DEAN: One person was killed, 15 others injured when a House exploded Monday afternoon in Marietta, Florida, about 70 miles north of San Diego. Crews from Southern California Gas were at the home repairing a natural gas line that was damage by contractor when the blast occurred.

[04:10:03] The person who died was a SoCalGas employee. Firefighters are among those being treated now. Details of the severity of their injuries have not been released.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh, God, I can't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Tears of joy after a missing camper in California is found alive. Sixty-year-old Sheryl Powell of Huntington Beach disappeared Friday near the Grand View campground in the Bristle Cohen Pine Forest. She had taken the family dog for a bathroom break. Authorities found the dog 2 1/2 miles where Powell was seen.

Her son believes someone threatened her. This is a photo of Sheryl reunited with her husband Joe and her children, Greg and Farrah (ph).

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Magnificent.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's a miracle.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: After so many days gone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Powell's son Greg tells CNN his mother was dehydrated but is doing well.

DEAN: Netflix has removed a controversial suicide scene from its hit teen drama "13 Reasons Why." The move follows a debate over whether the show increased the risk of teen suicide among its viewers. "13 Reasons Why" is the story of a depressed high school teenage girl and explains why she did it and who she blames.

In the first season's final episode story is told in flashback. Creator Brian Yorkey says: No one scene is more important than the life of the show. We believe this edit will help this show do the most good to most people while mitigating any risk for especially vulnerable young viewers.

BRIGGS: All right. Good move there.

Ahead, European leaders scrambling to save the Iran deal are downplaying recent violations of the agreement. A live report, straight ahead.

[04:16:30] BRIGGS: Four-sixteen a.m. Eastern Time.

And European leaders say Iran's breach of the nuclear deal is not significant as they scrambled to save the deal from collapse. But Iran's former minister says Tehran is not prepared to renegotiate.

CNN's Arwa Damon is live in Istanbul with the latest.

Arwa, good morning.

It almost thinks like Iran thinks they can intimidate European leaders into staying in this deal. How's it working out?

ARWA DAMON, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, it's not necessarily just an issue of Iran wanting to intimidate European leaders, Iran really is willing to go back to the original agreement. Iran's foreign minister said that they spent 12 years negotiating that agreement and Iran's position has been that they only began violating it because the U.S. withdrew and then slapped on unilateral sanctions. Iran's foreign minister said that America has declared an economic war in their country.

European nations are trying to salvage this original agreement. No one wants to see the situation escalate any further, and at this point, European parties to the agreement are not willing to invoke the mechanism that would see the agreement entirely fall apart.

Here's what the E.U.'s foreign policy chief had to say.

FEDERICA MOGHERINI, EUROPEAN UNION FOREIGN POLICY CHIEF: For the time being, none of the parties to the agreement signaled their intention to invoke this article, which means that none of them is for the moment, for the time being with the current data we have had, in particular from the IEA, that noncompliance is considered to be significant noncompliance.

DAMON: And Iran though for its part is saying that it will continue to increase its production of low grade uranium keeping in mind it is far, far, far away from reaching a nuclear weapon, but it is hoping that by threatening to increase production that will perhaps somehow put more pressure on European countries that will lead to some sort of pressure on the U.S. to back off of those brutal sanctions that the Trump administration has been posing.

But, of course, all of this comes at a time of significantly increased tensions in the region. And any sort of misstep, any sort of accident could lead to a devastating escalation, Dave.

BRIGGS: Indeed, it could. Arwa Damon, 11:18 there in Istanbul, thank you.

DEAN: A 27-year-old man has confessed to killing American scientist Suzanne Eaton on the Greek island of Crete. Police believe the 59- year-old molecular biologist went missing during a run two weeks ago while attending a conference. Her body was found deep inside a cave. Investigators say Eaton was asphyxiated and minor stab wounds were found on her body. More details about the suspect and Eaton's death are expected later today.

One hundred messages about child abuse and neglect went unread in Colorado. Why and what officials are saying now?

[04:24:36] BRIGGS: Barry is slowly weakening this morning but it will continue to pose a flooding threat over the next few days. One Louisiana family homeless after a bee infested tree crashed through their mobile home during the storm. Listen to this teen describe how his father tried to free his mother while the bees were attacking.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KAVIAN ROBERTSON, PARENTS ATTACKED BY BEES: My mom was screaming for help -- bees everywhere. I tried to help my mom but he wasn't -- he got trapped because the bees was eating him up everywhere -- eating them both up.

[04:25:05] His face was just so swelled up from bees.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Right now, heavy rain is spreading north into Arkansas, Missouri and Tennessee. And over 21 million people are currently under a heat warning or advisory.

DEAN: An Indiana police officer who shot and killed a black man from breaking into cars has resigned from the South Bend Police Department. The shooting of Eric Jack Logan in June aggravated years of racial tension between South Bend Police and the African-American community.

It also put a spotlight on South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg's challenge and gained the trust of minority voters. The police union says Sergeant Ryan O'Neill is stepping down due to job-related stress, and media attention on the case and hateful social media responses. He still faces a special prosecutor investigation and a lawsuit filed by Logan's family.

BRIGGS: A 2-year-old Michigan girl has gone missing. Police and family members searching a camp site for Gabriella Vitale. Her family called authorities Monday morning and said they were preparing to head home from a week-long camping trip when they lost track of their daughter. Gabriella's pink jacket was found several hundred yards from the camp site. She is believed to be wearing tennis shoes and a gray shirt. Sheriff's deputies and Michigan state police have canine teams searching the area.

DEAN: In Colorado, more than 100 messages about child abuse and neglect went unchecked for four years because an email account was set up and then forgotten. At least five child abuse cases that needed follow-up were not investigated. The email account was established in 2015 to support a phone hotline for abuse cases, part of the campaign to raise awareness for reporting of child abuse. The state department of human services says it's a great concern these cases did not get the attention they needed in a timely way.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIMBRO: There we go, there we go. Come on -- come on, baby. She's breathing. As long as she's crying like that, she's breathing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Dramatic bodycam video shows an officer saving the life of a 12-day-old baby. It happened after Deputy Will Kimbro had pulled over a car for speeding last month. The driver immediately got out of the vehicle and old him her baby had stop breathing.

Kimbro took the baby's limp body and performed life saving first aid, tapping her chest to clear the airway and massaging her heart. He kept at it until the paramedics arrived. The sheriff's office says the baby is doing well and Deputy Kimbro was given a medal for his life savings actions.

Kudos to you, Mr. Kimbro. Wow. Incredible video there.

DEAN: Not once, not twice, but three times the president digs in and defends racist tweets. He's digging him -- is he digging himself and his party into a hole they won't be able to escape come 2020 and beyond?

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKD-KV31-JB20-G52P-00000-00Trump Versus "The Squad"; Biden Versus Sanders on Health Care; Rays' D'Arnaud Hits 3 Home Runs to Beat Yankees. Aired 5-5:30a ET2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisEARLY START5:00 AM ESTNEWSInternational071603CN.V34Trump Versus "The Squad"; Biden Versus Sanders on Health Care; Rays' D'Arnaud Hits 3 Home Runs to Beat Yankees. Aired 5-5:30a ETDave Briggs, Jessica Dean, Andy Scholes

President Trump escalating the ugliest of ugly politics; instead of apologizing for his racist attack on four progressive House members, he justified it at a White House news conference. Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders square off on health care, a pivotal issue now dividing some Democrats. After he was dumped by the Mets for struggling for years, suddenly, Travis D'Arnaud is a Yankee killer after joining the Tampa Bay Rays.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: As far as I'm concerned, if you hate our country, if you're not happy here, you can leave.

REP. ILHAN OMAR (D-MN): This is the agenda of white nationalists.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DAVE BRIGGS, CNN ANCHOR: A defense of racism now an ironclad part of the president's playbook. His rhetoric met with mild criticism from the Republican Party he reshaped.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The transition of dropping 300 million people on a new plan are a little risky.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The system that Joe and others are trying to prop up is the most wasteful bureaucratic and expensive system on earth.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JESSICA DEAN, CNN ANCHOR: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders squaring off on health care. A pivotal issue now dividing some Democrats.

BRIGGS: Joy and relief after a missing hiker is rescued in California. Sheryl Powell went missing for four days. We'll tell you why.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DEPUTY WILL KIMBRO, BERKELEY COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE, BERKELEY COUNTY, SOUTH CAROLINA: There we go. There we go. Come on. Come on, baby. She's breathing. As long as she's crying like that, she's breathing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: A heart pumping rescue in South Carolina as a deputy pulls over a car for speeding and saves a baby in distress.

Good morning to you. Welcome to EARLY START. I'm Jessica Dean, in for Christine Romans today.

BRIGGS: Good morning. Good morning to all of you. I'm Dave Briggs. Tuesday, July 16th, 5:00 a.m. in the East.

Fifty years ago today, Apollo 11 launched and how far we've come, talking about racist statements from the president of the United States. President Trump escalating the ugliest of ugly politics. Instead of apologizing for his racist attack on four progressive House members, he justified it at a White House news conference.

Trump sparked the controversy Sunday when he tweeted the congresswomen, all of them U.S. citizens should, quote, go back to where they came from.

John Roberts of Fox News put this question to the president yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Does it concern you that many people saw that tweet as racist and that white nationalist groups are finding common cause with you on that point?

TRUMP: It doesn't concern me because many people agree with me and all I'm saying, they want to leave, they can leave.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: The episode reflects the president's certainty he won't lose the support of his base nor the Republican Party he reshaped.

DEAN: Most GOP lawmakers kept mum but a number of prominent lawmakers did come out against the remark if not against the president. The only black Republican in the House, Will Hurd of Texas.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. WILL HURD (R-TX): The tweets are racist and xenophobic. They're also inaccurate. It's behavior that's unbecoming of the president of the United States and the leader of the free world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: George Conway, Washington lawyer, Trump critic and husband of Kellyanne Conway wrote, quote, Sunday left no doubt. Naivete, resentment and outright racism roiled in a toxic mix, have given us a racist president.

Now the women Trump painted as the American hating face of the Democratic Party are pushing back.

We have more from White House correspondent Kaitlan Collins.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Dave and Jessica, not only is the president not backing off the remarks he made over the weekend, he's escalating his attacks on these four Democratic congresswomen, accusing them of hating the country and saying if they do not like living here, then they should leave.

He was at an event on the South Lawn of the White House when he came prepared with pieces of paper with bullet points to make the case where he said he felt he was in the right.

TRUMP: As far as I'm concerned, if you hate our country, if you're not happy here, you can leave. And that's what I say all the time. That's what I said in a tweet, which I guess some people think is controversial. A lot of people love it, by the way.

COLLINS: Now, the women that the president has accused and made these attacks on held a press conference yesterday where the four of them appeared on Capitol Hill to confront what the president said, statements they said they were not surprised by to come out of the president's mouth.

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY): Weak minds and leaders challenge loyalty to our country in order to avoid challenging and debating the policy.

OMAR: This is the agenda of white nationalists. Whether it is happening in chat homes or it's happening on national TV and now it's reached the White House garden.

COLLINS: I should note that Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader's office said we will hear from him at his normal press conference that he holds pretty much on a weekly basis.

And people will be watching to see what it is he has to say about these racist attacks coming from the president -- Jessica and Dave.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BRIGGS: Kaitlan, thanks.

The fight over health care now front and center in the race for the 2020 Democratic nomination. The issue increasing the friction between front-runner Joe Biden and challenger Bernie Sanders. The former vice president releasing a 10-year $750 billion proposal Monday, a plan that Sanders calls too wasteful and complicated.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: The system that Joe and others are trying to prop up is the most wasteful, bureaucratic and expensive system on earth. And when you talk about subsidies, what you're talking about is spending even more money, in this case taxpayer money, on a dysfunctional, wasteful and bureaucratic system. We need a simple system.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Albeit far more expensive.

[05:05:01] Arlette Saenz traveling with the Biden campaign in Iowa. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ARLETTE SAENZ, CNN POLITICAL REPORTER: Dave and Jessica, Joe Biden kicked off a three-day swing through Iowa here in Des Moines by touting his newly released health care plan which he says will build on the Affordable Care Act. Now, Biden's plan would provide a public option to allow Americans to buy into a Medicare type of program. It also provides massive subsidies to make purchasing insurance through the exchanges cheaper for all-Americans regardless of income.

Biden also insisting that Medicare for All isn't the answer when it comes to health care worrying that programs like that will be difficult to implement and also are, quote, kind of a little bit risky.

REPORTER: You're talking now about a public option as part of your health care plan?

BIDEN: Yes.

REPORTER: That was very tough the last time.

BIDEN: Sure it was.

REPORTER: When Obamacare was first coming around.

BIDEN: Sure it was.

REPORTER: And it didn't happen.

BIDEN: Can you imagine what Medicare for All, if you think that's tough? Come on. Look, here's the deal, guys. One of the things that's happening is, all of a sudden, the American public has figured out what Obamacare was about.

It's solid, it's real, it's consequential. And we can in fact for a significant portion of the price, we can in fact insure 97, 98 percent of all the American people who want to be insured, and they can keep their policy if they want.

SAENZ: Now, Biden was really focused in the past week and a half on establishing clear lines of differences between himself and his Democratic opponents who are supporting a plan like Medicare for All.

Now, Biden will continue promoting his health care plan over the next two days in Iowa, including making some stops in rural Iowa to talk about healthcare. We're also going to be hearing more about health care from Kamala Harris who has promised a policy proposal coming today. And Bernie Sanders will once again be making his case on Medicare for all on Wednesday.

These candidates clearly trying to draw their battle lines on health care heading into that next debate just over two weeks away -- Jessica and Dave.

(END VIDEOTAPE) BRIGGS: Arlette, thanks.

A check on CNN business at 5:06 Eastern Time. An unusual alliance in Washington. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Congresswoman Maxine Waters both coming out against Facebook's digital currency Libra. Lawmakers have expressed skepticism Facebook already under attack over privacy concerns can be trusted with the digital currency.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: To the extent that Facebook can do this correctly and can have a payment system, you know, correctly with proper AML, that's fine. They've got a lot of work to do to convince us to get to that place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Mnuchin's comments came as Facebook executive David Marcus prepares for a pair of hearings on Capitol Hill. In the remarks released ahead of the Senate Banking Committee Marcus wrote, quote, Facebook will not offer the Libra digital currency until we have fully addressed regulatory concerns and received appropriate approvals.

Libra also faces resistance in the House Financial Services on Wednesday. Congresswoman Maxine Waters who chairs that committee has drafted legislation that could block Facebook from operating Libra. The, quote, Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act would prevent all large finance companies from being involved in or becoming financial institutions. Libra is expected to launch in early 2020.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh, God, I can't believe it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: Tears of joy after a missing camper in California is found alive. Sixty-year-old Sheryl Powell of Huntington Beach disappeared Friday near the grand view campground in the Bristle Cone Pine Forest. She had taken the family dog for a bathroom break and her son believes someone threatened her, forcing her to run down the hill where she got lost. This is a photo of Sheryl reunited with her husband Joe and her children Greg and Farrah.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Magnificent. We were so --

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's a miracle.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's a miracle. After so many days gone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEAN: Powell's son tells CNN his mother was dehydrated but is otherwise doing well. BRIGGS: One hundred messages about child abuse and neglect went unread in Colorado. Why and what officials are saying now.

[05:14:02] BRIGGS: Five-Eastern Eastern Time.

And Barry is slowly weakening this morning, but it will continue to pose a flooding threat over the next few days. One Louisiana family is homeless after a bee infested tree crashed through their mobile home during the storm. Listen to this teen describe how his father tried to free his mom while the bees were attacking.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KAVIAN ROBERTSON, PARENTS ATTACKED BY BEES: My mom was screaming for help -- bees everywhere. I tried to help my mom but he wasn't -- he got trapped because the bees was eating him up everywhere -- eating them both up. His face was just so swelled up from bees.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Right now, heavy rain is spreading north into Arkansas, Missouri and Tennessee. Over 21 million people are currently under a heat warning or advisory. Highs will approach 100 degrees in New York City later this week.

DEAN: An historic opioid trial now in the hands of a judge. The state of Oklahoma and Johnson and Johnson sparring over whether the drug maker bears the blame for the state's opioid crisis.

[05:15:00] Oklahoma accuses Johnson and Johnson and its subsidiary Johnson of creating a public nuisance that cause the state billions. Johnsons and Johnson argues its vital pain medications aren't the cause of the complex opioid epidemic and that it has been made a scapegoat. The judge he'll take about a month to render a decision.

BRIGGS: The boxing world mourning the loss of legendary Pernell "Sweet Pea" Whitaker. He died after being hit by a vehicle while he was walking on Virginia Beach Sunday. Whitaker was just 55 years old. "Sweet Pea" rose to fame during the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, winning the gold medal in the lightweight division. He won titles in four different weight classes.

One of his boxing rivals, Oscar De La Hoya, tweeting it was an honor to share the ring with him in terms of his defense and ring generalship. Pernell Whitaker was the best fighter that I ever fought.

DEAN: In Colorado, more than 100 messages about child abuse and neglect went unchecked for four years because an email account was set up and then forgotten. At least five child abuse cases that needed follow-up were not investigated. That email account was established in 2015 to support a phone hotline for abuse cases. It was part of a campaign to raise public awareness of the state's resources for reporting child abuse. State department of human services says it's of great concern these cases did not get attention they needed in a timely way.

BRIGGS: Over 1 million people have signed up for a fake Facebook event, calling for a mass raid on Area 51 in September. The U.S. Air Force base in Nevada has long been a source of alien conspiracy theories. A pinned post on the Facebook page says: Hello, U.S. government, this is a joke.

But Air Force officials are not laughing. The bogus event has gained so much traction the Air Force is issuing a warning that Area 51 is an open training range and will be protected accordingly.

DEAN: Take a look at this giant barrel jellyfish spotted off the southwest of England. You see there, it's the size of a human. It was spotted by broadcaster and biologist Lizzie Daly and she described the moment she set eyes on the creature breathtaking and called the encounter unforgettable. Barrel jellyfish typically grows up to three feet in diameter and weigh 5 pounds. According to Daly, this one was at least as large as her.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KIMBRO: There we go, there we go. Come on -- come on, baby. She's breathing. As long as she's crying like that, she's breathing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BRIGGS: Dramatic bodycam video shows an officer saving the life of a 12-day-old baby. It happened after Deputy Will Kimbro had pulled over a car for speeding last month. The driver immediately got out of the vehicle and old him her baby had stop breathing.

Kimbro took the baby's limp body and performed life saving first aid, tapping her chest to clear the airway and massaging her heart. He kept at it until the paramedics arrived. The sheriff's office says the baby is doing well and Deputy Kimbro was given a medal for his life-savings actions.

Bravo, sir.

All right. Ahead, after he was dumped by the Mets for struggling for years, suddenly, he is a Yankee killer after joining the Tampa Bay Rays. Andy Scholes has that story in the "Bleacher Report".

[05:23:31] BRIGGS: You can add the Kansas City Royals now to a list of teams who will be extending their protective netting down the foul lines.

Andy Scholes has that story in the "Bleacher Report".

Good morning, my friend.

ANDY SCHOLES, CNN SPORTS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, good morning, Dave. You know, this is another case of a team being reactive instead of proactive. A 12-year-old girl unfortunately was hit by a foul ball on Sunday by the Royals game. According to the team she was being kept overnight at the hospital for observation. As a result, the Royals say they will be extending their protective netting down the foul line. They said they were already looking into extending the netting before Sunday's incident.

Last week, the Chicago White Sox were the first team to install protective netting for the season. Here's a list of teams who say they will be extending the netting before the start of next season. You have the White Sox, Nationals, Rangers, Dodgers, Royals, Orioles and the Pirates.

OK. NBA MVP Giannis Antetokounmpo hanging with the Yankees before their game last night. I'm going out on a limb say that Giannis hasn't played much baseball. He was struggling to hit the ball off the t.

Now, one guy who was connecting plenty last night was the Rays' Travis D'Arnaud. He tied the team record with three home runs and the last one was quite dramatic. It was top of the ninth, two outs, down two, two outs, full count and D'Arnaud connects for the go-ahead three-run home run off of Chapman.

[05:25:00] And thanks to D'Arnaud, the Rays stun the Yankees 5-4.

After the game, D'Arnaud, a former New York Mets, said it was the coolest night ever.

All right. Finally, we had an awesome moment before last night's Rockies game in Denver. Jamie Ketchum lost both her legs, an arm, a hand and suffered severe burns on 95 percent of her body after being in a fiery car crash that killed her father. Jamie spent 425 days in the hospital and has overcome incredible odds. She lived out a lifelong dream throwing out that first pitch before the game last night.

Dave, just an incredible moment. What a journey she has gone through to get to that moment. Props to her for just being such an inspiration.

BRIGGS: Remarkable moment there in Denver. Thanks so much, Andy Scholes.

Jessica, what's ahead?

DEAN: All right. Up next, not once, not twice but three times. The president digs in and defends racist tweets. Is he digging himself and his party a hole they won't be able to escape come 2020 and beyond?

Mike Lee (R-UT) Promises To Pass Green Card Giveaway By Sept. 27; Dems Demand Release Of Whistleblower Complaint Against President Trump2019-09-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:39:32ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTTom Fitton, Steven MnuchinNEWSFinancial092301cb.229Trump Versus The World; Trump Talks China Trade; Mnuchin On U.S.- China Trade; Quid-Pro-Joe; President Trump Defends Call With Ukrainian President; Trump: I May Release Transcript Of Call With Ukrainian President; Source: Whistleblower Didn't Have Firsthand Knowledge Of Trump Call; McCabe Memo Details Rosentein's Proposal To Wear A Wire To Tape Trump; DHS Plan To End Catch And Release For Border Families Next Week; WSJ: Sheldon Adelson Warned Trump About Impact Of US-China Trade War; Mnuchin: We'll Resume China Trade Talks After Next Week; Mnuchin: No Question Sanctions On Iran Are Working; Sen. Mike Lee (R-UT) Promises To Pass Green Card Giveaway By Sept. 27; Dems Demand Release Of Whistleblower Complaint Against President TrumpLou Dobbs, John Roberts, Ed Rollins

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. President Trump today bringing his America First agenda to the United Nations, to the general assembly. The president asserting America's leadership on the world stage the leader of the, well, free world at least, delivered a speech on religious freedom before meeting with six different world leaders.

The president took up everything from global extremism to the potential of the new fair and reciprocal trade deal with China.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If my opponent had won the election, China's economy would have surpassed the United States by now. And with me there's a tremendous difference. We're talking to China we have very serious conversations coming up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We'll have the very latest on those conversations as we talk with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Also tonight, more questions being asked about the credible claims of corruption in the Ukraine, surrounding former Vice-President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.

The 2020 Dem hopefully desperate to stick to the left's narrative, but President Trump some somehow committed an impeachable offense during a phone call with the leader of Ukraine.

The president today denied any abuse of power for political gain as we learn more about the so-called whistleblower at the blower at center of this latest contrive left-wing inspired political firestorm directed at president of United States.

Chief White House Correspondent, John Roberts with us right here in the studio tonight. Great to have you here, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Lou, good to see you. Of course, this whole controversy surrounds a complaint that was delivered to the intelligence community inspector general by this whistleblower, and sources tell Fox News that this whistleblower did not have firsthand knowledge of telephone conversation July 25th between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

What's more, the complaint that was delivered to the inspector general makes it clear that this whistleblower did not have firsthand knowledge.

We're also learning more about why this complaint was not delivered to Congress, the general counsel for the Office of the Director of National Intelligence in a statement saying, quote, "The complaint involves confidential and potentially privileged communications by persons outside the intelligence community, therefore the DNI lacks unilateral authority to transmit such materials to intelligence committees."

Now the general counsel's also consulted with inspector general about all of this, and here's what general counsel said about those consultations, quote, "Based on those consultations we determine that the allegations did not fall within the statutory definition of an urgent concern, and that the statute did not require the complaint that be transmitted to the intelligence committees on Capitol Hill."

The president today denying any wrongdoing in that telephone call that he had with the Ukrainian and the Ukrainian foreign minister, saying he knows what was talked about in that phone call and that there was quote, "No pressure put on President Zelensky by president Trump.

Now to prove his point, President Trump and the White House are considering releasing at least the partial transcript of that telephone call. Here's what the president said about that at the U.N. today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Perhaps you'll see it, perhaps you won't see that it depends on what we want to do. I can do it very easily but I'd rather not do it from the standpoint of all of other conversations I have.

I may do it because it was a very innocent call on both his part and mine. We had a very nice call. I hope you get to see it and I hope you get to see it soon.

(END VIDEO CALL)

ROBERTS: So that was the president talking about it, Lou, multiple times during his meeting with the President of Poland, Andrzej Duda. But there are reasons to not do it, first of all, precedent, I don't remember any time when a telephone conversation, a private conversation between the president of the United States and a foreign leader last been released.

Second, slippery slope, if the president releases the transcript of this phone call, do Democrats on Capitol Hill say, well we want to see your calls with Putin as well. And then do Republicans reciprocate by saying, we want to see all of President Obama's calls with world leaders.

And then third, there's the issue of would you have to redact sections of it for national security measures of classification? If there is one redaction in a transcript of a phone call that the Democrats are so hungry to get their hands on, they got to say, that invalidates the whole thing. You really got to take all of these into consideration.

DOBBS: The only part that catalogue that you've thrown out first to consider that I find attractive is listening to the conversations and reading the conservations transcripts of President Obama and the world leaders.

(LAUGHTER)

But I suspect that would be no more persuasive than to the Democrats looking at the transcript of that call. You know the president, his detractors are not going to be satisfied by facts, by truths, we know right now that this whole thing is built on hearsay, and a person without standing in the intelligence community.

We know that intelligence community itself has been hostile to this president to point of number of the agency --

ROBERTS: But I -- I think unless you release --

DOBBS: Well John, lets me finish.

ROBERTS: Sorry, go ahead. It's your show.

DOBBS: Well, it's also good manners.

(LAUGHTER)

The fact to the matter is that the agency chiefs had some role, we don't know yet quite what, in effort to subvert the president of the United States. Now, your turn.

ROBERTS: I was just going to say that unless the full and complete transcript of that phone call is released, Democrats will not buy it.

DOBBS: Yeah, they're not going to buy anything, truth, or anything approaching it. At least that's been our experience so far to with we might consider the special counsel report after almost two years of investigation. Great to see you.

ROBERTS: You too.

DOBBS: Thanks so much, John.

ROBERTS: All right, thank you.

DOBBS: Breaking tonight, a newly obtained memo finds former deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein told Andrew McCabe as he was serving as acting director of the FBI, that he would wear a wire to capture President Trump's quote, "True intentions over the firing of James Comey."

The memo released today by Judicial Watch is dated May 16, 2017, the day before Robert Mueller was appointed special council. Rosenstein insists the comments were sarcastic when he offered to wear that wire. But memo however shows McCabe thought Rosenstein was serious.

Joining me now, Tom Fitton, the president of Judicial Watch. And Tom, good to have you with us.

Let's start with first of all, Rosenstein's role in this, and what we know of his intentions, and how it is he survived this long if indeed those intentions were nefarious as some would claim?

TOM FITTON, JUDICIAL WATCH PRESIDENT: Well, it's no longer in the Justice Department, so, he was slowly rolled out the door, I guess. Because his explanations, I don't think were persuasive.

Certainly, Mr. McCabe his credibility is lacking what this memo is written the day of the meeting, and McCabe says, look he offered - this is the extraordinary thing, McCabe goes over the Rosentein's office says, I'm investigating the president.

And he says, you're a witness and Rosentein starts confessing and says, well we'll wire on the president. And McCabe says, well we'll get back to you, we'll ask our team about it.

Now, why would he pursue that if it was a sarcastic remark or evidently a sarcastic remark? But here you have McCabe and Rosenstein, both abusing their powers to target President Trump and seriously discussing, it looks like wearing a we're on the president, you've got McCabe on his own initiating a spy operation on the president, calling it a counter intelligence operation on the president.

All of this is documented in two pages. We had to wait over a year for it, for the FBI to finally cough it up. And this is exactly the sort of thing that the media doesn't want you looking at, as it plays its Ukraine gambit in latest iteration of their coup argument against President Trump.

This was the coup, the heart if it is here in this document and now we're talking about phone calls over Ukraine, unbelievable.

DOBBS: It is unbelievable particularly when you consider that now in a phased revelation if you will, following the onset of this manufactured nonsense, but again directed at president of United States to find that the whistleblower whoever he or she is, did not have firsthand knowledge, was operating purely on hearsay.

And furthermore, is not a person of the intelligence community and therefore could not hold whistleblower status. And what difference does that make? The Democrats continue their nonsense, braying in the dark with their usual ignorance and venality.

FITTON: Yeah, you know as I said on Twitter, Lou, and the president highlighted it. A malicious seditious conspiracy against the president.

Look, the idea that anyone that hears anything about what president says to foreign leader automatically has whistleblower status, you know what? I'm blowing whistleblower on Joe Biden. I want them Democrats to investigate Joe Biden now.

I'm blowing the whistle on Barack Obama, on Hilary Clinton, because I've got documentary evidence that all of them were involved in this coup conspiracy against President Trump.

Obviously, they're not going to follow-up on that as a matter of law, and nor should anyone else take seriously this obvious attempt to try to derail the president's ability to conduct foreign policy.

And let's be clear here, they want to freeze the president, he's not allowed to fire FBI director, he's not allowed to talk to foreign leaders, he's not allowed to exercise oversight over the corrupt FBI or DOJ, they want to make it impossible for him to do his job.

And when they do that, they're attacking our constitutional respect republic because we hired him to do the job and these folks need to get out of the way in terms of trying to improperly impair the functioning of this office.

DOBBS: I couldn't agree with you more, they should get out of the way but I would hope also at same time confess and turned themselves in for further, if you will, constructive rehabilitation should they decide to rejoin society.

Tom Fitton, great to have you with us. Thanks so much.

FITTON: You're welcome. Thank you.

DOBBS: The Department of Homeland Security is ending its so-called catch and release policy beginning next week. Acting Director Kevin McAleenan today said, ending the policy for Central American families is a vital step to restore rule of law and integrity to our immigration system.

Family apprehensions have risen 400 percent so far this year compared to same time a year ago.

Up next, President Trump calls out world leaders for shunning and worse, people of faith.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Too often people in positions of power preach diversity well, silencing, shunning or censoring the faithful, true tolerance means respecting the right of all people to express their deeply held religious beliefs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We take all of that and much more up with Pastor Robert Jeffers here later tonight.

Also, why is Wall Street trying turn cut the president's negotiating position with China? We'll take that up and much more with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin right after the quick messages.

DOBBS: Not a lot to report on Wall Street, so we won't. Stocks mixed, the Dow 15, the S&P flat, the Nasdaq down 5, volume on the big board dropping to 3.2 billion shares, crude oil up a percent, $58 a barrel, plus go about a percent, silver up nearly 5 percent.

WeWork CEO and co-founder Adam Neumann launching talks with investors in the board of directors talking about his future role with the company. Those for mentioned folks are not pleased with his performance.

According to Reuters, he may give up his title as CEO Softbank, WeWorks chief investor reportedly wants him to resign. WeWork, the latest IPO last week and it does appear that it will be going to market very soon.

A reminder, listen to my reports three times a day, coast-to-coast on The Salem Radio Network.

President Trump's tough stance with China rattling Wall Street, the business round table and the Chamber of Commerce from time to time. The Wall Street Journal reporting billionaire owner Sheldon Adelson warned the president about how tariffs might affect the economy, but the warning may have been somewhat personal to Adelson, his Las Vegas sands company makes just about 63 percent of its revenue from casinos in China. His company is licensed to operate is also set to expire in 2022.

Well, St. Louis Fed President, James Bullard today saying, it's inevitable that the United States and China would clash on trade. Bullard cited China's failure to live up to its WTO commitment when it joined the organization back in 2001.

In a statement Bullard said this, quote, "The Chinese were allowed into the WTO on an implicit promise that they would abide not just with the letter but the spirit of the World Trade Organization and that they would transition toward democracy. Neither of these things have happened."

Our next guest will be meeting with the vice premier of China in early October to resume trade talks. And joining us tonight, we're pleased to see the Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Great to have you with us --

STEVEN MNUCHIN, U.S. SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY: Great to be here, thank you.

DOBBS: Let's start with China and United States and where we are in the negotiations, if they could still be called that?

MNUCHIN: Well, I think you know Ambassador Lighthizer and I have been at this now for a while under the president's direction. And the president has been very clear, we get the right deal.

He wants to do a deal, if we can't get the right deal, he's happy with the tariffs.

DOBBS: And the Chinese position does not seem to have migrated toward anything approaching an end of threat of hundreds of billions of dollars in intellectual property and technology to balance trade is a preset of any agreement?

MNUCHIN: Well, from our first meeting with President Trump and President Xi, President Xi agreed that rebalancing the trade deficit was a priority. We've been working two years for that, and you're right it's gone in the other direction, so the president is determined that we have to have a fair and reciprocal relationship with trade, and it's been a one-way street.

DOBBS: It has been a one-way street since the beginning of the Chinese adventure, if you will, has it not? And to think that right now, agriculture is going to be the number one export of the United States.

It was only superpower, the most advanced economy and my god, we're locked up around soybeans and agriculture. It's just extraordinary to me as an outsider looking in, it's extraordinary that that would be our first move forward.

MNUCHIN: Well, it's not that agriculture is the most important issue. And the most important issue as you said is the intellectual property. But the farmers and the fisherman are very important to the president.

DOBBS: You think it ought to be important --

MNUCHIN: And I would say that you know, we take it as a personal offense that they stopped buying agriculture. Now, the good news that the Chinese have agreed, and they've started buying again.

DOBBS: Right.

MNUCHIN: So that's the good news, it's a sign of good gesture that they're back at table buying agriculture and those are important people who have supported president. So I'm a soybean's salesman.

DOBBS: Well, you know, I'm a soybean consumer like nearly everyone in this country and I appreciate that. I do find it a little difficult to understand why China is so reticent to acknowledge at least the fundamental precepts and I know that you and Trade Representative Lighthizer have been absolutely fantastic in your negotiations.

The president has I think been brilliant for example talking about Agriculture. He's moved back significant billions of dollars, what is it? About $26 billion to the farmers out of that almost now more than $70 billion in tariffs.

I mean that's an extraordinary to me an innovative way in which to deal with the problems at agriculture.

MNUCHIN: I agree, and the president was determined to make sure that the farmers were not collateral damage --

DOBBS: Right.

MNUCHIN: -- in these discussions. But the good news is I think there is a desire for China to move forward with these reforms. They have their own issues internally, I think they're focused on, and we have a good framework of an agreement. We'll see if we can move forward with that.

DOBBS: And we mentioned this Sheldon Adelson, was telling apparently according to the report in the Wall Street Journal that you know that he didn't think it was such a great idea to proceed with tariffs and to disrupt the relationship.

But understandably, his most of his revenue comes from Macau, it is a hotbed of gambling enterprise. But again it's not - just would expect there to be less vested interested in the counsel given the president.

MNUCHIN: Well, I've known Sheldon for over 20 years and he's really a great businessperson and he's -

DOBBS: No doubt.

MNUCHIN: -- he's been a great supporter of the president during the campaign when other people weren't stepping up, Sheldon was stepping up. So, I do think he has the right intentions.

I mean as you said, he does have interest there, but I think one of the issues, he has a pretty good perception from having done business in China. And that's really his counsel but Sheldon wants to see the right outcome here, he understands issues of intellectual property, and this is the first president that's confronted these issues.

DOBBS: It is stunning when we think about the chronic year after year trade deficits with China and Wall Street arguing that it is not a zero-sum game, that there is no effect on economic growth even though we know it does affect national savings and it does in fact reduce the rate of economic growth in this country.

This president and you, and the Lighthizer have stood up against the Chinese, and I have to say probably they spent the first year just trying to get over their shock that an of American government would say no, you can't loot diligent plunderers any longer.

MNUCHIN: Well as you know, the president not only like tariffs but he uses them strategically.

DOBBS: Absolutely.

MNUCHIN: And he's right, if it weren't for the tariffs nobody would be at the table negotiating. So, this is really an important tool in rebalancing this relationship.

DOBBS: And talks will be underway shortly to do just that, we're going to continue our conversation with the Treasury Secretary, Steven Mnuchin right after these very quick words, please stay with us.

DOBBS: We're back with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Mr. Secretary, where are we in terms of talks with vice premier, you referred to him today at United Nations. When will you resume these talks?

MNUCHIN: It's actually, I think not next week, it's the following week we'll be having those talks. We have deputy level talks last week. And made a little bit of progress on that front and we look forward to meeting with the vice premier.

DOBBS: And at the U.N. today, there was just a moment, it seemed uncertainty at least on the part of the media, as to whether or not the Chinese delegation had chosen to skip the agriculture talks in Montana and Nebraska or whether or not treasury and trade representative had suggested to them that they skip it. Can you clear that?

MNUCHIN: I just wanted to clarify because I didn't --

DOBBS: Sure.

MNUCHIN: -- want people to think that they cancelled the trip and that meant they weren't buying agriculture. They are buying agriculture. We just decided the timing of the trip wasn't necessarily the perfect timing. So they'll rescheduling that to after our trade meetings.

DOBBS: When you say we, you're referring to you and Lighthizer?

MNUCHIN: Exactly, Bob and I.

DOBBS: Okay, great. Let's go to another very important and I think most people would probably be surprised to learn just how much of your time is spent on national security on sanctions approaching at least half your time, right?

MNUCHIN: It is.

DOBBS: And Iran, we're at a juncture that I think very few people saw arriving. That is with tensions at a height, and the president cool headedly, and constrained not unleashing the hounds of hell. Give us your sense of where we are and how sanctions in fact working?

MNUCHIN: Well, let me just put this in perspective because I think you know, the president campaigned on that he was going to reap up the Iran nuclear deal, that it was a terrible deal, and that it would have allowed Iran to end up with nuclear weapons, at the end of a relatively short-term.

And also had many other things that didn't address, so when the president came in, he did that. He instructed us to put the sanctions back on. These have been the toughest sanctions that have ever in place and there's no question they're working, we've cut off the money to Iran and that money was being used to spread terrorism.

DOBBS: Sanctioning now, even the central bank?

MNUCHIN: Yes, so the president did three things recently, one was he authorized us to put sanctions on the central bank and the sovereign well fund but we're using money for terror.

He also agreed to send a couple of hundred troops for defensive purposes to Saudi and expedite arm sales.

DOBBS: And the consequence because these sanctions have been in effect, they have obviously the gradation has been to tighter and stronger sanctions throughout.

But these sanctions now are severe as they are, does it mean that Iran in your judgment will be forced to come to a negotiating table and to change their waves?

MNUCHIN: Well I don't want to predict what they'll do but I will say is they are working so there is no question that they are working and that they're cutting off the source of funds.

DOBBS: And the maximum pressure campaign, are you now at maximum pressure in these sanctions, or is there still room to inflict further burden on the Iranians if they continue as they have?

MNUCHIN: We're almost at maximum pressure with Iran but more importantly, we still have the ability to go after third parties that violate our sanctions and that will really be the focus of what we're working on now at-this-point.

DOBBS: Talking about the constraints, Huawei, their role now is - it's ambiguous where they stand within both our national security as well as national economic policies.

The Europeans have not eagerly at least moved toward the same degree of concern about the espionage organization of the PLA. Your thoughts?

MNUCHIN: Well, I want to be careful what I say because obviously, I have access to a lot of information on this. The first issue and really the most important issue is we want to make sure that the U.S. government and our allies are not using Huawei equipment in our infrastructure and that's really something we're focused on.

As it relates to selling things to them, I think you know, some of the stuff are commodity items that we make, that South Korea makes, and some of them are more strategic.

So, there's really two different issues, one is what we're buying from them, and two is what we're selling to them.

DOBBS: And as we conclude here, the relationship with business in this country, there has never been a better president in the first --in his first term in office and we know there'll be two, for business, for markets, and yet we have a Wall Street that has been resistant to balance trade with China.

They are not being particularly helpful, they, being the be community in fighting against the policies of this president, and you, and Robert Lighthizer on balancing trade. You call it rebalancing and I would call it for the first time truly a balancing.

What more would you ask of - it just seems to me that something should be asked of business community, of Wall Street to assist this government in pursuing national economic and national security policy because in many instances they are working against the interest of the country?

MNUCHIN: Well I think as you said, this president a very much pro- business, and pro-economy president. So, when we came in, there were three parts, first was tax cuts, historic tax cuts. Number two was regulatory relief which allowed us to really do business properly again, and the third is trade.

And I think there are a lot of people in the business community that are supportive of the trade. I think there's also a lot of people who realize that China is a giant market, that if U.S. companies and U.S. workers can compete fairly in China, that's a tremendous opportunity for U.S. business and U.S. workers. So that's a big priority for us.

DOBBS: I understand, but I don't understand why there isn't at least an expression of reciprocity and some gratitude for the leadership of the president and his policies that would assure some alignment between Wall Street, the Chamber of Commerce, and the business roundtable with you and Robert Lighthizer.

Mr. Secretary, great talking with you, I appreciate it, look forward to talking with you soon.

MNUCHIN: Great to be here. Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Thank you and much luck. Up next, we take a look at a bill, Senator Mike Lee is trying to force through the Senate. Oh, man, does it have interesting sponsors, and you know outsourcing, and American workers, it's a problem in that bill. We take it up right after these quick messages, stay with us.

DOBBS: There's something percolating in U.S. Senate right now that I wanted to bring to your attention because it is a very serious matter. Rino Senator Mike Lee has put forward a plan this week to -- as he is the lead sponsor to push through legislation that would be detrimental to the American worker.

No ifs, ands, or buts, about it. Lee Senate Bill 386, it's called the fairness for high skilled immigrants act. Think about this, fairness for high skilled immigrants act, it would remove green card Limits. He will allow largest the countries, India and China, those two countries to pack green card lines with as many H-1B visa workers as they like all eager to take up U.S. jobs and historically its significantly lower pay.

Pushing this legislation are companies like Cognizant, and Deloitte, who are two of the biggest sponsors of H-1B visa workers all of America. The U.S. Chamber of Commers, also that's where they're working and they are pushing like the dickens as is Microsoft and Google's parent, Alphabet.

In this recent election cycle, that is the last election cycle. Senator Lee has raked in tens of thousands of dollars from big tech companies, including more than 33,000 from Microsoft, about 18,000 from Google just for openers.

Joining us tonight, former Reagan White House political director, Republican strategies, Fox Business political analyst, the most knowledgeable person in this country, I know on politics. Good to have you, Ed.

ED ROLLINS, GREAT AMERICA PAC CHAIRMAN: Thank you. This is a critical bill for two reasons, one is the president has made a commitment to create jobs for Americans and particularly young Americans coming out of college, and what have you with engineering degrees and health care degrees, what have you.

And now you basically, this bill would create a competition for them by giving these visas to Indian students who come here and particularly, you know, which is a country of a billion people, give them jobs at lower rates, lower wages than the Americans --

DOBBS: But typically, somewhere around 20 to 30 percent lower wages, than prevailing wages.

ROLLINS: Right. Absolutely.

DOBBS: Even though we're talking about high skilled workers, they're often in jobs that your four basic quadrants of skill and they're usually in lowest of those four levels that define the H1-B visa.

ROLLINS: As we've talked so many times, immigration is such a critical issue here and we always have to make sure that American students, American -- young Americans seeking jobs they have the benefit of their education and that their competition is among themselves initially.

And without creating this false competition by giving all these students from India advantages or the visa. And I think to certain extent this bill is kind of a sleeper bill being pushed through by --

DOBBS: They tried to run it by with unanimous consent last week, and Senator Perdue stopped it because he was uncomfortable, he said with the language.

I was cheering Senator Purdue until then I found out he'll support it once they fix a little bit of the language which I again led this considerable disappointment. Yes, I've been hanging around politics so long, I still get disappointed and this is one --

ROLLINS: Well this is one of those bills, it's an imperfect bill, they admitted it's an imperfect bill. And to me, anything that relates to immigration at this point in time needs to get perfectly a lot of imperfect bill.

And anything that's detriment to the young Americans coming out of college and universities with technical skills should be looked at --

DOBBS: This president is the president of the working man and woman -

ROLLINS: And he promised that too, right?

DOBBS: And you know, these senators need to be very careful about the position they put the president in. Radical Dems, quote, unquote "Whistleblower," who doesn't know while they has no personal knowledge of anything? Isn't a member of the intelligence community, and therefore isn't a whistleblower entitled to any kind of protections.

I guess we should just ask this person who the hell told that you all this nonsense.

ROLLINS: Well this is all part of deep state again that we've been fighting now for two years here and I think the reality is that as Rudy Giuliani is so very effectively put, you know Biden's young son has been out there doing some things.

DOBBS: Well the president makes it very clear.

ROLLINS: Right.

DOBBS: We need to know what happened out there.

ROLLINS: And we should.

DOBBS: And I have loved the fact that the Dems just hate the idea that president of the United States can ask a question of a foreign leader.

(LAUGHTER)

ROLLINS: And the reality is -

DOBBS: And you've got Adam Schiff out there. Ed, he's at it again. Lying through his teeth and just lied.

ROLLINS: He's been so dismissed but you have to understand, he is the speaker in waiting as far as Nancy Pelosi is concerned.

DOBBS: He's a fraud in the present.

ROLLINS: And I think they're looking for any excuse to hold his impeachment hearings. This is --

DOBBS: Well, let them have at it. They might as well --

ROLLINS: Let them go, let them go, they're not going to win it, and this is stupid, and they want to expose Biden.

DOBBS: If they want to indulge in self-emulation then you know --

ROLLINS: But the one thing is the national news media, it thus need to get after this situation, I mean you know in those tickets. Otherwise, there's, you know they have no credibility.

DOBBS: This is a comedy act. This is a comedy act. A whistleblower who isn't a whistle blower who is complaining about something he does not know or she doesn't heard, I mean you know that's perfect for Saturday Night Live not for the house of representatives or the Senate.

And it's always great to see you, partner.

ROLLINS: Thanks my friend. You take care.

DOBBS: Thank you, you too partner.

Cory Lewandowski join us next, the former Trump campaign manager and senator to be perhaps, we'll find out. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Joining me now, former Trump campaign manager and author Corey Lewandowski and soon to be senator? How about that? Let's get that out of way right now. You want to declare here tonight or?

COREY LEWANDOWSKI, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN MANAGER: Well, Lou, you know I told you when I'm ready to go, I'm going to let you know first and the Q3 fundraising numbers are due out here very shortly, right end of September.

And I've said very publicly if the Republican declared candidates in state of New Hampshire can't raise money commensurate with what it takes to beat an incumbent two term senator that, it's going to push me further into the race.

And after last week's fiasco in front of the house judiciary committee, I don't think another person should ever have to be treated the way I was which was so rude, the name-calling, the disrespect that those committee members showed me, I may run for the U.S. Senate just in case.

DOBBS: I thought they were very nice to you Corey? I thought they were very respectful.

(LAUGHTER)

I mean for Democrats.

LEWANDOWSKI: I don't think President Swalwell (ph) was that nice. President Swalwell (ph( wasn't that nice, Lou.

DOBBS: Well, let's turn to what's going on right now. The whistleblower, your thoughts?

LEWANDOWSKI: Lou, my cousin's sister's brother's dog, this is like theme out of baseball the movie told me the story, right. And so, all of a sudden, I'm a whistleblower. Of course, that's not the case. This is a person who has no direct knowledge of the conversation who heard it at a bar that was on a cocktail napkin that given to him by his cousin's friend who might have worked in the White House one day.

DOBBS: I think you're expecting too much of people, Corey. I mean first of all, you feel, well you know, insulted and affronted by the Radical Dems on Judiciary Committee and now you think a whistleblower should actually know what the hell he or she is talking about at firsthand experience and be a member of the intelligence community in which they are seeking whistleblower status. This is amazing.

LEWANDOWSKI: This is crazy talk. But look, if you're going to actually hear the conversation then you've had to actually have heard the conversation. This person never actually heard the conversation.

And they were so insulted by what they heard, they decide to go to a person who said, you have no credibility in this conversation, so we're not going to pursue this. That's the chaos.

But Lou, you know this. The mainstream media --

DOBBS: They love it.

LEWANDOWSKI: -- hates this president more than they love the country. And what that means is anything to stop Donald Trump.

DOBBS: I think you're exactly right. Corey, great to have you with us. And by the way, this is where you're going to announce your senatorial run, right?

LEWANDOWSKI: Lou, if I do it, I'm coming here, you know that.

DOBBS: You got it. All right, you're on the record.

LEWANDOWSKI: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: And I know you want to now you top start with a clean record. Thanks so much.

LEWANDOWSKI: Yes, I do.

DOBBS: Thanks so much.

(LAUGHTER)

Thanks, Corey. Corey Lewandowski. Joining me now, Pastor Robert Jeffress, member of the White House Faith Initiative Pastor The First Baptist Church of Dallas, Fox Business contributor, the president today Pastor, actually I mean taking up for the world to hear the religion liberties as a priorities of this president and this nation.

PASTOR ROBERT JEFFRESS, WHITE HOUSE FAITH INITIATIVE MEMBER: And the first time in history any leader of any nation has ever spoken to the U.N. on that topic, that is unbelievable. But he was addressing a real problem, he did it with passion, he did it honestly.

And look, Lou, this was right thing to do morally, but it was a brilliant thing to do politically. I mean instead of going to some boring summit on climate change and imaginary problem, he says, to heck with that, and he has his own conference on a real problem, religious liberty.

There is no president in history that would have the guts to do what this president did today.

DOBBS: You know and he's had a lot of days like today.

JEFFRESS: Yes.

DOBBS: No previous president would have had the guts to do because they didn't do it. They had opportunity whether it is standing up for this nation and international trade, whether it is making a partner of Mexico.

Putting tens of thousands of troops on the borders of south and northern borders of Mexico to stop illegal immigration, the list goes just on and on, tearing up what was the so-called legacy of Barack Obama.

JEFFRESS: You know watching him deal with the Democrats, Lou, it reminds me of that Road Runner cartoon, Road Runner and Wild Coyote. Road Runner was always out smarting the Coyote. They thought they had even a box and they didn't.

The Dems have not been able to catch him yet. They felt that having trapped in this global climate thing today, he said the heck with that, I'm going to have my own summit. This is the leadership that infuriates his enemies and makes his people love him.

DOBBS: And by the way, it's great for America. Pastor, as are you, appreciate it. Pastor Robert Jeffress, thanks so much.

JEFFRESS: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: We'll be right back, stay with us.

DOBBS: A few concluding thoughts tonight on a few of this historic president's detractors and of course the Radical Dems who oppose everything he intends and achieves and a word or two of caution to them.

Let's begin with Mitt Romney, a tire-sen fellow with their rule over one, his latest tweet is so pathetic it begins with a hypothetical quote. If the president asked who are pressured et-cetera, et-cetera, Romney is a know nothing, and the worst kind of rino who wanted to lead but who can't now follow the nation's true leader.

It doesn't matter to Romney or the Radical Dems that the so-called whistleblower has no firsthand knowledge of anything that president's enemies claimed, but that was enough for the ignored than the venal to charge head long into fabrications and absurdly baseless calls to impeach the president.

These people are worse than fools, they know better and still they lie. But this time they've been caught early. And the person who is being hosted with the left's petard is none there than sleepy Joe Biden himself because these are his words.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VP OF THE UNITED STATES: You're not getting the bill and I will be leaving here, and I think about six hours, I'm leaving in six hours. If the prosecutor is not fired, you're not getting the money.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Now dear Dem hopefuls and leftist media, Biden is in full glaring focus. And now finally, we're about to watch what appears to be the beginning of an investigation of the Obama-Biden era and all of the political corruption it spawned.

That's it for us tonight. We thank you for being with us. Tomorrow night, Judge Jeanine Pirro and Sebastian Gorka among our guests. And we hope you all join us.

A reminder to follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

Thanks for being with us tonight, see you here tomorrow. Good night from New York.
